description: This is a content model for features representing of lithology log intervals associated with a borehole. Each interval has a top and a bottom, measured from the ground surface (convention for interoperability). Each interval has a geologic unit description that will be identical with the content associated with polygons on a geologic map.
title: Borehole Lithology Interval Feature
discussion: This template defines the content model for a service that delivers borehole lithology log interval observations. Many of these will be standard depth to interval, formation name and measurement procedure, but other information may be delivered. Much of the variation will concern procedures used to recorded the information, citations, and possible other collected data that may be useful for geothermal resource research. The  content model should be used when compiling geo data from published reports, databases, logging events and field notes. The content model presented here is intended to present key information necessary to query a borehole lithology interval observation service and to evaluate the data. Borehole interval are OGC sampling features, analogous to GeoSciML mappedFeature.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: OBJECTID
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: BHIntervalURI
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Unique identifier that specifies the  borehole interval. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: WellName
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: APINo
BoreholeLithInterval.description:
API number for the the wellbore/borehole identified by the HeaderURI. If an API number is unavailable this field is empty. Usage of hyphens is optional, according to standard practice in each state. API number refers to the American Petroleum Institute number. Each oil, gas, or geothermal well drilled in the United States has a unique API number; this number identifies all boreholes or recompletions associated with the original wellbore. See 
							http://www.spwla.org/technical/api-technical for more information about API numbering.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: OtherID
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Alternative identifier(s) for the feature. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe '|' character. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the prefix would be azgs: and the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: OtherName
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Other human-intelligible labels for feature such as secondary name or common name, other spellings. Indicate the authority from which the OtherName is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: BoreholeName
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Human-intelligible name by which the borehole identified by the HeaderURI is known. Convention for wellName is: Name = Operator + Well No. + Lease Owner. A well may consist of multiple boreholes (wellbores). If these are distinguished by different records in this table, they should have the same well names, but distinct BoreholeNames, and at least one identifier (APINo or OtherID) that is unique to the borehole. Conditional obligation - If the HeaderURI identifies a borehole which is one of several within a well, then a BoreholeName is mandatory. Each borehole should have a unique BoreholeName. Separate multiple BoreholeNames with the pipe character '|'.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: Label
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as feature name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: ParentWellURI
BoreholeLithInterval.description: The unique identifier for the well that contains the wellbore identified by WellBoreURI.   If the WellBoreURI identifies one of several wellbores within a well, this element is mandatory. Best practice is to define an http URI that will dereference to a normative description of the well.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: HeaderURI
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Unique identifier for the borehole indicated by this record. This identifier should identify the physical well, based on the API number if available. Otherwise, the URI should incorporate one of the OtherID values. Please contact the USGIN development team at AZGS for instructions.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: SpudDate
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Date on which drilling of the well bore began. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1' . If year is unknown, enter 1900. All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm. This is intended as a searching aid.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: EndedDrillingDate
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Date on which drilling of the well bore ended. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1'. If year is unknown, enter 1900. All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm. This is intended as a searching aid.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: DrillingMethod
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Basic drilling technology used in the creation of the borehole identified by the HeaderURI. Separate multiple drilling methods with the pipe  '|' character.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: WellType
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Type of well that contains the borehole identified by the HeaderURI, at the time indicated in the StatusDate element.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: Status
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Status of the feature at the time indicated in the StatusDate element. If unknown enter "unknown" in the field.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: StatusDate
BoreholeLithInterval.description: The status of the feature can change from time to time, thus it is useful to know the date on which a given status was reported. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: IntervalName
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Common or human-readable name by which the interval is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: Description
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Free text description of material in this lithology interval. This is considered mandatory, the simplest and minimum amount of information necessary to define why this interval is differentiated from other adjacent intervals in the borehole.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: IntervalType
BoreholeLithInterval.description: The interval type based on the method used to collect the measurement of the borehole interval. Default is Lithology Interval.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: County
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: State
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: LocationName
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Names of geographic features associated with the site that will be useful as search criteria to locate the information for this site. If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: LatDegree
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature (use center point for areas); values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: LongDegree
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature (use center point for areas); values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: SRS
BoreholeLithInterval.description: The spatial reference system. It is recommended that an EPSG code be used to identify the SRS used to specify the location.  If an EPSG code is used, identify it as such with the prefix 'EPSG:' EPSG:4326 is the identifier for WGS84, and should be the text in this field. EPSG stands for European Petroleum Survey Group. EPSSG codes can be dereferenced by putting the code in this URL (replace 4326) http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/4326/.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: DepthTopInterval
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Depth to the top of the borehole interval identified by the BHIntervalURI, from borehole origin to top of borehole interval.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: DepthBottomInterval
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Depth to the bottom of the borehole interval identified by the BHIntervalURI, from borehole origin to bottom of borehole interval.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: DepthReferencePoint
BoreholeLithInterval.description: The point of reference against which elevation measurements are made. Best practice: use mean sea level (MSL) as datum.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: ElevationGL
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Elevation in feet at ground level at the well collar location. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL).

BoreholeLithInterval.name: LengthUnits
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Units used to report all elevation and depth information.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: WellBoreShape
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Term used to indicate the overall shape of the borehole identified by the HeaderURI, e.g. vertical, inclined down, curved, horizontal, inclined up, unknown.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: TrueVerticalDepth
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Vertical distance from bottom hole point to elevation of borehole origin.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: Permeability
BoreholeLithInterval.description: The property or capacity of a porous rock, sediment, or soil for transmitting a fluid; it is a measure of the relative ease of fluid flow under unequal pressure.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: UnitsPermeability
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Units for the reported permability. The SI unit for permeability is m^2. A practical unit for permeability is the darcy (D), or more commonly the millidarcy (mD) (1 darcy \approx10−12/m^2).

BoreholeLithInterval.name: Porosity
BoreholeLithInterval.description: The percentage of pore volume or void space, or that volume within rock that can contain fluids.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: UnitsPorosity
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Units of porosity are percent.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: ObservationMethod
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Report any information pertaining to measurements of the borehole interval, including porosity, permeability, geologic history or other tests performed and data reported. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: GeologicUnitName
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Name of geologic unit that was sampled. Include hierarchy of names if the unit is part of a higher-rank geologic unit, e.g. Group name/Formation name, or Formation/Member, or Group/ Formation. Spell out unit names in full.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: SpecificationURI
BoreholeLithInterval.description: This URI could refer to a GeoSciML feature that describes the instance in detail.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: GeologicHistory
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Free text description of age or history of the feature.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: RepresentativeAgeURI
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Unique identifier for a named time era that best characterizes the age of the interval. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: YoungerAgeURI
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Unique identifier for younger age term for interval.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: OlderAgeURI
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Unique identifier for older age term for interval.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: Rank
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Term may use formal stratigraphic rank terms (member, formation, group, bed) or informal rank terms.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: Lithology
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Description of the lithology of surface geology or geologic column for well interval, e.g. arkose, granite, limestone, sandstone, schist. Recommend using CGI simple lithology vocabulary. Use to account for EarthChem Material, EarthChem Type, EarthChem Composition, alluvium, 36-40': gravels; etc.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: RepresentativeLithologyURI
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Unique identifier that specifies a category in a lithology generalization scheme. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: RelatedResource
BoreholeLithInterval.description: This may be one to many http links to resources (logs, pictures or other documents if available online. Should be an http:// address (URL)) related to the observation described in each record. Delimit multiple values with the pipe '|' character.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: Source
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining this feature or record; may be author-date type citation, well log, report, data files etc., but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe '|' character.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: MetadataURI
BoreholeLithInterval.description: URI identifying (and ideally dereferencing to get) a full formal metadata record for the observation report. A time series of observations may all reference the same metadata record that provides contact information and details on procedure, etc.

BoreholeLithInterval.name: Shape
BoreholeLithInterval.description: Added by GIS for WFS service; this element appears in the xml output, but is generated during service deployment from the latitude and longitude, therefore it doesn't appear in the template.

label: bhlithinterval

status: Current services are deployed using content model version 1.5.  For use in GeoServer, please see the app-schema mapping file 'BoreholeTemperature.xml' at http://repository.stategeothermaldata.org/resources/documents/App-Schema-Mapping-Files/bht/azboreholetemperatures/.   SLDs (Styled Layer Descriptors) can be downloaded from the State Geothermal Data Repository.   The legend for the Borehole Temperatures model is a point-feature color ramp which ranges from green (≤95F) to red (≥ 212F) for each feature.
description: This is a data interchange content model for a subsurface temperature measurement made in a borehole. Header content that characterizes the borehole sampling feature is included with each observation to assist users finding measurements based on location, depth, particular borehole, etc. This information will be provided through a borehole temperature observation service. The HeaderURI for a particular borehole (well for simple wells) is the cross-referencing link (foreign key) used to associate the header record, well logs, temperature measurements, and other information from a particular borehole.
title: Borehole Temperature Observation
discussion: The idea is that each record (feature) in an interchange document represents an individual observation. Thus there are multiple records if there are multiple observations in a single borehole, indexed by depth, procedure, time of observation properties. It’s a data access format, so this results in lots of duplication of the header/indexing information, but keeps life simpler for the client application. This becomes problematic in the continuum from single temperature measurements to a discrete log with measures every 100’ to a continuous temperature log; it’s sort of arbitrary when one switches from the individual temperature measure as being the observation to the ‘log view’ in which the series of measures is the observation result (currently represented as an excel spreadsheet or LAS file)—based mostly on what we think will be most useful to our customers.

BoreholeTemperature.name: OBJECTID
BoreholeTemperature.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

BoreholeTemperature.name: ObservationURI
BoreholeTemperature.description: Unique identifier for this observation record. This is the identifier (Uniform Resource Identifier) that will be used to cross-reference logs, samples and other observations to the well or borehole represented by this header. If available, the API (American Petroleum Institute) assigned number is the preferred well name reference. If an APINo is not available, observationURI should include one of the 'OtherID' values (below). If the API number indicates multiple instances of reentry, recompletion, sidetrack, etc., each instance is to have its own HeaderURI.  For example, the API number 42-501-20130-0300 indicates a well (42-501-20130) with three sidetracks, for a total of four total boreholes (-0000,-0100, -0200,-0300), each of which should have its own database record and HeaderURI.

BoreholeTemperature.name: WellName
BoreholeTemperature.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

BoreholeTemperature.name: APINo
BoreholeTemperature.description: API number for the the wellbore/borehole identified by the HeaderURI. If an API number is unavailable this field is empty. Usage of hyphens is optional, according to standard practice in each state. API number refers to the American Petroleum Institute number. Each oil, gas, or geothermal well drilled in the United States has a unique API number; this number identifies all boreholes or recompletions associated with the original wellbore. See the Data Valid Terms tab or http://www.spwla.org/technical/api-technical for more information about API numbering

BoreholeTemperature.name: HeaderURI
BoreholeTemperature.description:
Unique identifier for this observation. This is the identifier (Uniform Resource Identifier) that will be used to cross-reference data, samples, and other observations to the observation represented by this record. Best practice is to define an http URI that will dereference to a normative description of the observation. USGIN URI's may be redirected to any URL using the http://resources.usgin.org redirector; contact the USGIN development team at AZGS for instructions.

							If the API number indicates multiple instances of reentry, recompletion, sidetrack, etc., each instance is to have its own HeaderURI.  For example, the API number 42-501-20130-0300 indicates a well (42-501-20130) with three sidetracks, for a total of four total boreholes (-0000,-0100, -0200,-0300), each of which should have its own database record and HeaderURI.

BoreholeTemperature.name: OtherID
BoreholeTemperature.description: Alternative identifier(s) for the feature. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe '|' character. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the prefix would be azgs: and the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

BoreholeTemperature.name: OtherName
BoreholeTemperature.description: Other human-intelligible labels for feature such as secondary name or common name, other spellings. Indicate the authority from which the OtherName is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

BoreholeTemperature.name: BoreholeName
BoreholeTemperature.description: The human-intelligible name of the borehole identified by the HeaderURI.

BoreholeTemperature.name: Label
BoreholeTemperature.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as feature name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

BoreholeTemperature.name: Operator
BoreholeTemperature.description: Name of company/organization that is operating the well during the reporting period.

BoreholeTemperature.name: LeaseName
BoreholeTemperature.description: Name or number of the lease of the well that contains the borehole identified by the HeaderURI.

BoreholeTemperature.name: LeaseOwner
BoreholeTemperature.description: Companies, individuals, or other entities who own the property. Separate multiple with a pipe '|' character.

BoreholeTemperature.name: LeaseNo
BoreholeTemperature.description: Lease number of the borehole identified by the HeaderURI.

BoreholeTemperature.name: SpudDate
BoreholeTemperature.description: Date on which drilling of the well bore began. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1' . If year is unknown, enter 1900. All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm. This is intended as a searching aid.

BoreholeTemperature.name: EndedDrillingDate
BoreholeTemperature.description: Date on which drilling of the well bore ended. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1'. If year is unknown, enter 1900. All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm. This is intended as a searching aid.

BoreholeTemperature.name: WellType
BoreholeTemperature.description: Type of well that contains the borehole identified by the HeaderURI, at the time indicated in the StatusDate element.

BoreholeTemperature.name: Status
BoreholeTemperature.description: Status of the borehole at the time indicated in the StatusDate element. If unknown enter "unknown" in the field.

BoreholeTemperature.name: CommodityOfInterest
BoreholeTemperature.description: The commodity of interest associated with the borehole.

BoreholeTemperature.name: StatusDate
BoreholeTemperature.description: The status of the feature can change from time to time, thus it is useful to know the date on which a given status was reported. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

BoreholeTemperature.name: Function
BoreholeTemperature.description: Functional characterization of the borehole identified by the HeaderURI.

BoreholeTemperature.name: Production
BoreholeTemperature.description: Term indicating the production results of the borehole identified by the HeaderURI.

BoreholeTemperature.name: ProducingInterval
BoreholeTemperature.description: Name of producing interval or intervals in well; separate multiple interval names by '|' character.

BoreholeTemperature.name: ReleaseDate
BoreholeTemperature.description: Date on which data for the borehole identified by the HeaderURI was, or will be, made public.

BoreholeTemperature.name: Field
BoreholeTemperature.description: Name of the field in which the borehole is located. If multiple names are or have been used for the field, separate values with a pipe '|' character.

BoreholeTemperature.name: OtherLocationName
BoreholeTemperature.description: Names of geographic features associated with the site that will be useful as search criteria to locate the information for this site. Separate multiple keywords with the pipe '|' character.

BoreholeTemperature.name: County
BoreholeTemperature.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

BoreholeTemperature.name: State
BoreholeTemperature.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

BoreholeTemperature.name: PLSS_Meridians
BoreholeTemperature.description: List north-south baseline and east-west meridian that Townships and Ranges are referenced to.

BoreholeTemperature.name: TWP
BoreholeTemperature.description: Township in PLSS grid, relative to reported baseline. Formatting and punctuation should be consistent for all locations referenced to the same baseline and meridian. Recommend adding leading '0's so that all number strings are the same length (typically 2 or occasionally 3 digits). Examples 01N, 112S, 001N.

BoreholeTemperature.name: RGE
BoreholeTemperature.description: Range in PLSS grid, relative to reported meridian. Formatting and punctuation should be consistent for all locations referenced to the same baseline meridian. See instructions on TWP field.

BoreholeTemperature.name: Section_
BoreholeTemperature.description: PLSS section number. Must be numeric or null. Some surveys include half sections indicated by a 'nn.5' designation, where n indicates a number.

BoreholeTemperature.name: SectionPart
BoreholeTemperature.description: Subdivision of a PLSS section.

BoreholeTemperature.name: Parcel
BoreholeTemperature.description: Legal parcel identifier, or block number, or other location identifier.

BoreholeTemperature.name: UTM_E
BoreholeTemperature.description: UTM easting coordinate as decimal number.

BoreholeTemperature.name: UTM_N
BoreholeTemperature.description: UTM northing coordinate as decimal number.

BoreholeTemperature.name: UTMDatumZone
BoreholeTemperature.description: The datum and UTM zone for the reported coordinates. Datum for most locations should be NAD27 or NAD83.

BoreholeTemperature.name: LatDegree
BoreholeTemperature.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature (use center point for areas); values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

BoreholeTemperature.name: LongDegree
BoreholeTemperature.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature (use center point for areas); values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

BoreholeTemperature.name: SRS
BoreholeTemperature.description: The spatial reference system. It is recommended that an EPSG code be used to identify the SRS used to specify the location. If an EPSG code is used, identify it as such with the prefix 'EPSG:' EPSG:4326 is the identifier for WGS84, and should be the text in this field. EPSG stands for European Petroleum Survey Group. EPSSG codes can be dereferenced by putting the code in this URL (replace 4326) http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/4326/.

BoreholeTemperature.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
BoreholeTemperature.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

BoreholeTemperature.name: LocationUncertaintyCode
BoreholeTemperature.description: A controlled vocabulary term or code value specifying the location confidence, e.g. 1 = reported, 2= surveyed, 3= GPS. If such a code list or vocabulary is used, it must be added to the 'Data Valid Terms' sheet to enumerate the possible values and their meaning

BoreholeTemperature.name: LocationUncertaintyRadius
BoreholeTemperature.description: Radius (in meters) of circle of confidence for location. Ideally might represent some specific confidence criteria like 'radius of circle around reported location which which true location lies with 95% confidence', but such precision is rarely available.

BoreholeTemperature.name: DrillerTotalDepth
BoreholeTemperature.description: Length of borehole, from borehole origin to bottom of borehole.

BoreholeTemperature.name: DepthReferencePoint
BoreholeTemperature.description: The point of reference against which elevation measurements are made. Best practice: use mean sea level (MSL) as datum.

BoreholeTemperature.name: LengthUnits
BoreholeTemperature.description: Valid choices for units = Meters or Feet. If depth is reported as 'surface' or 'missing', select 'meters'.

BoreholeTemperature.name: WellBoreShape
BoreholeTemperature.description: Term used to indicate the overall shape of the borehole identified by the HeaderURI, e.g. vertical, inclined down, curved, horizontal, inclined up, unknown.

BoreholeTemperature.name: TrueVerticalDepth
BoreholeTemperature.description: Vertical distance from bottom hole point to elevation of borehole origin.

BoreholeTemperature.name: ElevationKB
BoreholeTemperature.description: Elevation at kelly bushing for the feature. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL).

BoreholeTemperature.name: ElevationDF
BoreholeTemperature.description: Elevation at drilling floor for the feature. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL).

BoreholeTemperature.name: ElevationGL
BoreholeTemperature.description: Elevation at ground level at the well collar location. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL).

BoreholeTemperature.name: FormationTD
BoreholeTemperature.description: Name of geologic unit at the bottom of the well or borehole.

BoreholeTemperature.name: BitDiameterCollar
BoreholeTemperature.description: Bit diameter at the origin of the borehole, reported in decimal format.

BoreholeTemperature.name: BitDiameterTD
BoreholeTemperature.description: Bit diameter at the bottom of the borehole, reported in decimal format.

BoreholeTemperature.name: DiameterUnits
BoreholeTemperature.description: Units of length used to specify diameters in this record. Inches  or centimeters, in decimal units.

BoreholeTemperature.name: Notes
BoreholeTemperature.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about collection method, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

BoreholeTemperature.name: MaximumRecordedTemperature
BoreholeTemperature.description: For clarity, it is assumed that one temperature will be recorded as a bottom hole temperature, therefore, the "MeasuredTemperature" field should be used.

BoreholeTemperature.name: MeasuredTemperature
BoreholeTemperature.description: Report temperture here if instrument records temperature and depth; this may be the same value as reported in the maximum temperature column; if a value is reported here, a DepthOf Measurement value must be reported. At least one Maximum or Measured Temperature is required.

BoreholeTemperature.name: CorrectedTemperature
BoreholeTemperature.description: Report the corrected formation temperature in this field.

BoreholeTemperature.name: TemperatureUnits
BoreholeTemperature.description: Report temperatures in either degrees Fahrenheit or Celsius. Use same units throughout this document.

BoreholeTemperature.name: TimeSinceCirculation
BoreholeTemperature.description: Time since circulation of drilling fluid stopped, in decimal hours. Made string to enable text (e.g., units or less than, more than qualifiers).

BoreholeTemperature.name: CirculationDuration
BoreholeTemperature.description: Time that hole was circulated after drilling stopped, in decimal hours; (not available in many cases).

BoreholeTemperature.name: MeasurementProcedure
BoreholeTemperature.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

BoreholeTemperature.name: CorrectionType
BoreholeTemperature.description: Please add your correction type name and a brief description of the correction method used for this.  Use this term to populate the template.

BoreholeTemperature.name: DepthOfMeasurement
BoreholeTemperature.description: Valid choices for units = Meters or Feet, in decimal format. If depth is reported as 'surface' or 'missing', select 'meters'.

BoreholeTemperature.name: MeasurementDateTime
BoreholeTemperature.description: Date for the record: date on which observation, measurement or test was made or specimen was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

BoreholeTemperature.name: MeasurementFormation
BoreholeTemperature.description: Name of geologic unit from which temperature was measured. Include hierarchy of names if the unit is part of a higher-rank geologic unit, e.g. Group name/Formation name, or Formation/Member, or Group/ Formation. Spell out unit names in full.

BoreholeTemperature.name: MeasurementSource
BoreholeTemperature.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining this feature or record; may be author-date type citation, well log, report, data files etc., but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe '|' character.

BoreholeTemperature.name: RelatedResource
BoreholeTemperature.description: This may be one to many http links to resources (logs, pictures or other documents if available online. Should be an http:// address (URL)) related to the observation described in each record. Delimit multiple values with the pipe '|' character.

BoreholeTemperature.name: CasingLogger
BoreholeTemperature.description: The deepest cased depth encountered during a log run in the borehole.

BoreholeTemperature.name: CasingBottomDepthDriller
BoreholeTemperature.description: Bottom of cased interval of the borehole as reported by the driller.

BoreholeTemperature.name: CasingTopDepth
BoreholeTemperature.description: Top of cased interval of the borehole.

BoreholeTemperature.name: CasingPipeDiameter
BoreholeTemperature.description: Diameter of the casing.

BoreholeTemperature.name: CasingWeight
BoreholeTemperature.description: Casing pipe weight per length installed in the borehole.

BoreholeTemperature.name: CasingWeightUnits
BoreholeTemperature.description: Units for the reported Casing Weight.

BoreholeTemperature.name: CasingThickness
BoreholeTemperature.description: Thickness Casing pipe installed in the borehole. Units must be same as diameter units specified in this record. If multiple pipe thicknesses used,  these should be separated by the pipe character '|'.

BoreholeTemperature.name: DrillingFluid
BoreholeTemperature.description: Name or type of fluid used during drilling.

BoreholeTemperature.name: Salinity
BoreholeTemperature.description: Salinity of the drilling fluid.

BoreholeTemperature.name: MudResistivity
BoreholeTemperature.description: Resistivity of the drilling fluid.

BoreholeTemperature.name: Density
BoreholeTemperature.description: Mud weight.  The density of the drilling fluid.

BoreholeTemperature.name: FluidLevel
BoreholeTemperature.description: The depth, or distance from surface, that the fluid in a well incapable of natural flow will reach under static conditions;.reported in same units as reported in LengthUnits.

BoreholeTemperature.name: pH
BoreholeTemperature.description: Report the pH of the drilling fluid (no units) in standard pH format.

BoreholeTemperature.name: Viscosity
BoreholeTemperature.description: The viscosity of the drilling fluid; resistance to flow.

BoreholeTemperature.name: FluidLoss
BoreholeTemperature.description: Leakage of the liquid phase of drilling fluid containing solid particles into the formation matrix.

BoreholeTemperature.name: MeasurementNotes
BoreholeTemperature.description: Additional notes regarding the measurement(s).

BoreholeTemperature.name: InformationSource
BoreholeTemperature.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining this feature or record; may be author-date type citation, well log, report, data files etc., but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe '|' character.

BoreholeTemperature.name: Shape
BoreholeTemperature.description: Added by GIS for WFS service; this element appears in the xml output, but is generated during service deployment from the latitude and longitude, therefore it doesn't appear in the template.

label: boreholetemperature

status: Version 1.0 has been approved for use by the NGDS working group.
description: This information exchange specifies content elements for an interchange format for linear spatial features representing contour (isoline) data. These lines connect locations registering the same value for some variable. Examples include structure contour maps that represent lines of constant elevation on some surface, or gravity anomaly contours that represent lines of constant anomaly value. Fields in the content model will become XML elements in interchange documents for WFS simple features served by geothermal data web services.
title: Contour Lines

ContourLine.name: OBJECTID
ContourLine.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

ContourLine.name: contourURI
ContourLine.description: Unique identifier that specifies the feature represented: e.g. a geologic feature, aquifer or facility structure. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature.

ContourLine.name: name
ContourLine.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature (contoured variable, e.g. "Great Unconformity", "Base of Mississippian", 'bouguer gravity anomaly', 'thicnkess of Monterey Formation') is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

ContourLine.name: description
ContourLine.description: Free text field for any additional observations or other information regarding the feature, any special considerations with this instance. If there is a description of the nature of the contoured surface, that should go here, or any other information useful to understand the data.

ContourLine.name: contourType
ContourLine.description: Term classifying the variable that is contoured.

ContourLine.name: contourValue
ContourLine.description: The value that the curve represents in decimal format.

ContourLine.name: units
ContourLine.description: Units used to report contour values.

ContourLine.name: observationMethod
ContourLine.description: Text indication of how the spatial extent of the feature was determined. ObservationMethod is a convenience property that provides a quick and dirty approach to observation metadata when data are reported using a feature view (as opposed to observation view). Recommend use of one of the CGI vocabulary terms from the FeatureObservationMethod or MappedFeatureObservationMethod in this workbook. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

ContourLine.name: positionalAccuracy
ContourLine.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

ContourLine.name: RelatedResources
ContourLine.description: This may be one to many http links to resources (logs, pictures or other documents if available online. Should be an http:// address (URL)) related to the observation described in each record. Delimit multiple values with the pipe character '|'.

ContourLine.name: source
ContourLine.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining this feature or record; may be author-date type citation, well log, report, data files etc., but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe '|' character.

ContourLine.name: contourType_uri
ContourLine.description: Unique identifier referring to a controlled concept from a vocabulary defining the Contact types. Mandatory property - if no value is provided then a URI referring to a controlled concept explaining why the value is nil must be provided.

ContourLine.name: specification_uri
ContourLine.description: Unique identifier that specifies the feature represented: e.g. a geologic feature, aquifer or facility structure. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature.

ContourLine.name: metadata_uri
ContourLine.description: URI identifying (and ideally dereferencing to get) a full formal metadata record for the feature. A time series of observations may all reference the same metadata record that provides contact information and details on procedure, etc.

ContourLine.name: genericSymbolizer
ContourLine.description: Identifier for symbol for default portrayal of this feature in some symbol scheme. This is a convenience value, and assumes the existence of SLD or other legend-type artifact that maps from these symbol identifiers to graphical elements. Required. Recommend use of FGDC symbol code used to portray the feature (contour type) on map.

ContourLine.name: Shape
ContourLine.description: Added by GIS for WFS service; this element appears in the xml output, but is generated during service deployment from the latitude and longitude, therefore it doesn't appear in the template.

label: contourlines

Version 1.5 has been submitted to NGDS technical team review, and the Excel workbook has been adopted for NGDS partner projects and posted on the NGDS web site resources/public documents section.
description: Direct use features describe facilities that utilize geothermal energy directly without transformation to electricity. See the NREL Geothermal Direct Use web page for more information. The template here is based on the Direct Use Site spreadsheet provided by the  GeoHeat  center at the Oregon Institute of Technology.
title: Direct Use Feature
discussion: This template defines the content model for a service that delivers Geothermal Direct Use site features. Many of these will be standard map location and IDs, but other information may be delivered. The geothermal direct use content model should be used when compiling data from published and unpublished reports, maps and databases. The content model presented here is intended to present key information necessary to query a direct use feature service and to evaluate the information.

DirectUseSite.name: OBJECTID
DirectUseSite.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

DirectUseSite.name: FeatureURI
DirectUseSite.description: Unique identifier that specifies the feature represented: e.g. a geologic feature, aquifer or  facility structure. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature.

DirectUseSite.name: SiteName
DirectUseSite.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

DirectUseSite.name: Label
DirectUseSite.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as feature name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

DirectUseSite.name: FeatureType
DirectUseSite.description: Type of feature that is the subject of this record. 'Facility', 'Thermal Spring', 'Borehole', etc.

DirectUseSite.name: County
DirectUseSite.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

DirectUseSite.name: State
DirectUseSite.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

DirectUseSite.name: OtherLocationName
DirectUseSite.description: Names of geographic features associated with the site that will be useful as search criteria to locate the information for this site. If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'.

DirectUseSite.name: UTM_E
DirectUseSite.description: UTM easting coordinate as decimal number.

DirectUseSite.name: UTM_N
DirectUseSite.description: UTM northing coordinate as decimal number.

DirectUseSite.name: UTMDatumZone
DirectUseSite.description: The datum and UTM zone for the reported coordinates. Datum for most locations should be NAD27 or NAD83.

DirectUseSite.name: LatDegree
DirectUseSite.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

DirectUseSite.name: LongDegree
DirectUseSite.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

DirectUseSite.name: SRS
DirectUseSite.description: The spatial reference system. It is recommended that an EPSG code be used to identify the SRS used to specify the location.  If an EPSG code is used, identify it as such with the prefix 'EPSG:' For common EPSG codes, see the Data Valid Terms tab. EPSG:4326 is the identifier for WGS84, and should be the text in this field. EPSG stands for European Petroleum Survey Group. EPSSG codes can be dereferenced by putting the code in this URL (replace 4326) http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/4326/.

DirectUseSite.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
DirectUseSite.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

DirectUseSite.name: LocationUncertaintyCode
DirectUseSite.description: A controlled vocabulary term or code value specifying the location confidence, E.g. 1 = reported, 2= surveyed, 3= GPS. If such a code list or vocabulary is used, it must be added to the 'Field List' sheet to enumerate the possible values and their meaning.

DirectUseSite.name: LocationUncertaintyRadius
DirectUseSite.description: Radius (in meters) of circle of confidence for location. Ideally might represent some specific confidence criteria like 'radius of circle around reported location which which true location lies with 95% confidence', but such precision is rarely available.

DirectUseSite.name: LocationKeyword
DirectUseSite.description: Names of geographic features associated with the site that will be useful as search criteria to locate the information for this site. If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'.

DirectUseSite.name: Status
DirectUseSite.description: Status of the feature; if unknown enter "unknown" in the field.

DirectUseSite.name: StatusDate
DirectUseSite.description: The status of the feature can change from time to time, thus it is useful to know the date on which a given status was reported. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

DirectUseSite.name: HeatApplication
DirectUseSite.description: Statement for how heat is being used. Should come from controlled vocabulary.

DirectUseSite.name: Temperature
DirectUseSite.description: Water temperature, in decimal format. Degrees Celsius is preferred and will be reported for consistency in service implementations.

DirectUseSite.name: TemperatureUnits
DirectUseSite.description: Report temperatures in either degrees Fahrenheit or Celsius. Use same units throughout this document.

DirectUseSite.name: MeasurementProcedure
DirectUseSite.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

DirectUseSite.name: Flow
DirectUseSite.description: Fluid production flow rate, reported in decimal format.

DirectUseSite.name: FlowUnits
DirectUseSite.description: Units for flow rate, either gallons per minute (gpm) or liters per minute (lpm).

DirectUseSite.name: FlowMeasurementProcedure
DirectUseSite.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

DirectUseSite.name: MeasurementDateTime
DirectUseSite.description: Date for the record (date on which observation, measurement or test was made or specimen was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

DirectUseSite.name: Capacity
DirectUseSite.description: Heat production capacity of facility, in decimal format.

DirectUseSite.name: CapacityUnits
DirectUseSite.description: For interoperability use MW (megawatt). BTU (British Thermal Units) also may be used.

DirectUseSite.name: CapacityProcedure
DirectUseSite.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

DirectUseSite.name: EnergyUse
DirectUseSite.description: Energy used by the facility, on annual basis.

DirectUseSite.name: EnergyUseUnits
DirectUseSite.description: Mandatory if energy use reported. Use GWh/yr (Gigawatt hours/year) for interoperability. MillionBTU and 10E12TJ/yr also possible.

DirectUseSite.name: EnergyUseProcedure
DirectUseSite.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

DirectUseSite.name: LoadFactor
DirectUseSite.description: Heating factor in BTUs.

DirectUseSite.name: FacilityContact
DirectUseSite.description: Person, organization, or position name for information about the facility.

DirectUseSite.name: PostalAddress
DirectUseSite.description: Postal address for facility. Street, City, State.

DirectUseSite.name: Zip
DirectUseSite.description: Zip code for facility; may be used for some geolocation information.

DirectUseSite.name: Phone
DirectUseSite.description: Telephone number to contact party connected with facility.

DirectUseSite.name: EMailAddress
DirectUseSite.description: E-mail address to contact party connected with facility.

DirectUseSite.name: Source
DirectUseSite.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining this feature or record; may be author-date type citation, well log, report, data files etc., but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe '|' character.

DirectUseSite.name: MetadataURI
DirectUseSite.description: URI identifying (and ideally dereferencing to get) a full formal metadata record for the feature. A time series of observations may all reference the same metadata record that provides contact information and details on procedure, etc.

DirectUseSite.name: Notes
DirectUseSite.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about collection method, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

DirectUseSite.name: Shape
DirectUseSite.description: Added by GIS for WFS service; this element appears in the xml output, but is generated during service deployment from the latitude and longitude, therefore it doesn't appear in the template.

label: directusesite

status: Services are currently deployed using this 1.8 schema. However, THIS CONTENT MODEL HAS BEEN SUPERSEDED. PLEASE USE THE WELL TESTS CONTENT MODEL. The new Well Tests information exchange allows for more types of well tests than simply drill stem tests.
description: THIS CONTENT MODEL HAS BEEN SUPERSEDED. PLEASE USE THE WELL TESTS CONTENT MODEL. This spreadsheet defines the schema used for the interchange of drill stem test observation results by the AASG geothermal data project for the National Geothermal Data System. The HeaderURI for a particular borehole (well for simple wells) is the cross-referencing link (foreign key) used to associate the header record, well logs, temperature measurements, and other information from a particular borehole. At minimum the data will report Observation URI, Well Header URI, Well Name, API No, DST Name, DST Operator, Lat Degree, Long Degree, SRS, DST Target Formation, Depth Top Open Zone, Depth Bottom Open Zone, Pressure Initial Shut In, Pressure Final Shut in, Hydrostatic Pressure, Source, and Information Source.
title: Drill Stem Test Observations (deprecated)
discussion: The idea is that each record (feature) in an interchange document represents an individual observation. Thus there are multiple records if there are multiple observations in a single borehole, indexed by depth to the open zone, procedure, and information source. It’s a data access format, so this results in lots of duplication of the header/indexing information, but keeps life simpler for the client application. Ideally formation and flow history will be reported.
label: drillstemtest

status:
No Services currently deployed using this content model.

This content model has been culled from the previous "Fluid Flux Borehole Observation" content model, along with the Well Fluid Production and the Geothermal Fluid Production content models.  Version 1.0 has been submitted for NGDS technical team review, and the Excel workbook has been adopted for NGDS partner projects and posted on the NGDS web site resources/public documents section.
description: This workbook documents a content model for exchange of information about fluid fluxes into or out of a well. A generic model is intended to allow for oil, gas, or water injection (negative flow). The focus of this observation type is on injection (any fluid flowed into well) or disposal. Because of the wide variety of possible flow measurements (commodities, aggregation type), the model adopts a thin approach, which may result in many records being returned for a single well. Thus most data about the well is linked through the HeaderURI instead of included inline to keep the redundant data volume down.
title: Fluid Flux Injection and Disposal
discussion: Many of these fluid production observations will be a standard map location and production volume, but other information may be delivered. This content model is designed to be used for data compilation from publications, reports, and databases. This content model is intended to present key information necessary to query an injection and disposal fluid production observation service and to evaluate the reported data.

FluidFluxInjection.name: OBJECTID
FluidFluxInjection.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

FluidFluxInjection.name: ObservationURI
FluidFluxInjection.description: Unique identifier for this observation. This is the identifier (Uniform Resource Identifier) that will be used to cross-reference data, samples, and other observations to the observation represented by this record. Best practice is to define an http URI that will dereference to a normative description of the observation. USGIN URI's may be redirected to any URL using the http://resources.usgin.org redirector; contact the USGIN development team at AZGS for instructions.

FluidFluxInjection.name: RecordName
FluidFluxInjection.description: Common or human-readable name for the record. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

FluidFluxInjection.name: Notes
FluidFluxInjection.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about collection method, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

FluidFluxInjection.name: FacilityURI
FluidFluxInjection.description: Unique identifier that specifies the feature represented (facility). Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature.

FluidFluxInjection.name: Operator
FluidFluxInjection.description: Name of company/organization that is operating the well during the reporting period.

FluidFluxInjection.name: HeaderURI
FluidFluxInjection.description: Unique identifier for the borehole indicated by this record. This identifier should identify the physical well, based on the API number if available. Otherwise, the URI should incorporate one of the OtherID values. Please contact the USGIN development team at AZGS for instructions.

FluidFluxInjection.name: WellName
FluidFluxInjection.description: Human-intelligible name by which the feature is known. Convention for wellName is: Name = Operator + Well No. + Lease Owner. A well may consist of multiple boreholes (wellbores). If these are distinguished by different records in this table, they should have the same well names, but distinct BoreholeNames, and at least one identifier (APINo or OtherID) that is unique to the borehole.

FluidFluxInjection.name: APINo
FluidFluxInjection.description: API number for the the wellbore/borehole identified by the HeaderURI. If an API number is unavailable this field is empty. Usage of hyphens is optional, according to standard practice in each state. API number refers to the American Petroleum Institute number. Each oil, gas, or geothermal well drilled in the United States has a unique API number; this number identifies all boreholes or recompletions associated with the original wellbore. See the Data Valid Terms tab or http://www.spwla.org/technical/api-technical for more information about API numbering.

FluidFluxInjection.name: OtherID
FluidFluxInjection.description: Alternative identifier(s) for the feature. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe '|' character. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the prefix would be azgs: and the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

FluidFluxInjection.name: County
FluidFluxInjection.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

FluidFluxInjection.name: State
FluidFluxInjection.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

FluidFluxInjection.name: Field
FluidFluxInjection.description: Name of the field in which the borehole identified by the HeaderURI is located. If multiple names are or have been used for the field, separate values with a '|' character.

FluidFluxInjection.name: OtherLocationName
FluidFluxInjection.description: Names of geographic features associated with the site that will be useful as search criteria to locate the information for this site. If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'.

FluidFluxInjection.name: LatDegree
FluidFluxInjection.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

FluidFluxInjection.name: LongDegree
FluidFluxInjection.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

FluidFluxInjection.name: SRS
FluidFluxInjection.description: The spatial reference system. It is recommended that an EPSG code be used to identify the SRS used to specify the location.  If an EPSG code is used, identify it as such with the prefix 'EPSG:' EPSG:4326 is the identifier for WGS84, and should be the text in this field. EPSG stands for European Petroleum Survey Group. EPSSG codes can be dereferenced by putting the code in this URL (replace 4326) http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/4326/.

FluidFluxInjection.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
FluidFluxInjection.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

FluidFluxInjection.name: IntervalStartDateTime
FluidFluxInjection.description: Start Date for the record: date on which observation, measurement or test was made or specimen was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

FluidFluxInjection.name: IntervalEndDateTime
FluidFluxInjection.description: End Date for the record:(date on which observation, measurement or test was made or specimen was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

FluidFluxInjection.name: DurationDays
FluidFluxInjection.description: Duration of injection interval described in this record. For interoperability, this interval should be reported in decimal days.

FluidFluxInjection.name: Permit
FluidFluxInjection.description: Permit for the fluid transfer activity during this reporting interval. Provide sufficient information to uniquely identify the permit.

FluidFluxInjection.name: FluidType
FluidFluxInjection.description: Please use Commodity of Interest vocabulary. Use multiple records (separate multiples with a pipe '|' character) if multiple fluids were produced or injected during reported interval.

FluidFluxInjection.name: FluidVolume
FluidFluxInjection.description: Total amount of fluid volume produced by the well during the production interval for this record.

FluidFluxInjection.name: FluidVolumeUnits
FluidFluxInjection.description: Unit of measurement used; for liquids the preference is 'gallon'.

FluidFluxInjection.name: Temperature_F
FluidFluxInjection.description: Average temperature, in decimal format, of the fluid injected over the course of the time interval for this record.

FluidFluxInjection.name: Pressure_psi
FluidFluxInjection.description: Pressure at which fluid is injected; nillable.

FluidFluxInjection.name: AggregationType
FluidFluxInjection.description: The method for recording the interval for temperature and pressure, e.g. minimum, maximum, average, spot.

FluidFluxInjection.name: InjectionOrDisposal
FluidFluxInjection.description: Term that specifies whether the record refers to injection (negative flow) or disposal (movement out of a well).

FluidFluxInjection.name: MeasurementMethod
FluidFluxInjection.description: Text description of how the measurements, in the FluidVolume_Gallons, and AverageTemp_F fields, was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

FluidFluxInjection.name: ContactIntervalTop
FluidFluxInjection.description: Top of interval in well from which fluid is injected. Use PPDM (Professional Petroleum Data Management Association) term for interval of well that is coupled to wall rock for fluid transfer.

FluidFluxInjection.name: ContactIntervalBottom
FluidFluxInjection.description: Bottom of interval in well from which fluid is injected. Use PPDM (Professional Petroleum Data Management Association) term for interval of well that is coupled to wall rock for fluid transfer.

FluidFluxInjection.name: Source
FluidFluxInjection.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining this feature or record; may be author-date type citation, well log, report, data files etc., but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe '|' character.

FluidFluxInjection.name: MetadataURI
FluidFluxInjection.description: URI identifying (and ideally dereferencing to get) a full formal metadata record for the observation report. A time series of observations may all reference the same metadata record that provides contact information and details on procedure, etc.

FluidFluxInjection.name: RelatedResources
FluidFluxInjection.description: This may be one to many http links to resources (logs, pictures or other documents if available online. Should be an http:// address (URL)) related to the observation described in each record. Delimit multiple values with the pipe character '|'.

FluidFluxInjection.name: Shape
FluidFluxInjection.description: Added by GIS for WFS service; this element appears in the xml output, but is generated during service deployment from the latitude and longitude, therefore it doesn't appear in the template.

status: Version 2.0 has now been approved by GeoSciML committees for use.
description: The ContactFeature tab of this workbook indicates the content for Geologic Contact features. The entirety of the workbook is an information exchange workbook for GeoSciML-Portrayal, in which three features for WFS implementation are described (see alsohttp://schemas.usgin.org/models/#geosciml-portrayal-units and http://schemas.usgin.org/models/#geosciml-portrayal-faults). The model is based on the IUGS CGI interoperability working group. See https://www.seegrid.csiro.au/wiki/CGIModel/GeoSciMLPortrayalViewModel. This schema is a view of GeoSciML data that de-normalizes the data and concatenates complex property values into single, human-readable, labels and returns single, representative values from controlled vocabularies for multi-valued properties that can be used when generating thematic maps, or portrayals, of the data. It is separate to, but harmonized with, GeoSciML and conforms to the level 0 of the Simple Features Profile for GML (link). Labels, will be 'free-text' fields that will be, in robust services, well-structured summaries of complex GeoSciML data, while the representative thematic properties will be URIs of concepts in a controlled vocabulary. There may also be links, via identifier URIs, to full GeoSciML representations of the geologic features.

ContactView.name: positionalAccuracy
ContactView.description: Quantitative values define the radius of an uncertainty buffer around a mappedFeature (eg: a positionAccuracy of 100 m for a line feature defines a buffer polygon of total width 200 m centred on the line).
