HeatFlow.description: Report temperatures in degrees Fahrenheit or Celsius. Use same units throughout this document.

HeatFlow.name: TemperatureMeasureType
HeatFlow.description: Method used to collect temperatures. Valid terms include: BHT (Bottom Hole Temperature from well log header), EQ (Equilibrium or precision data collected using temperature logging gear), MRT (Maximum Reading Thermometers), PL (from Pressure Log), Inferred (e.g. from Heat Production), Other, or Unknown.

HeatFlow.name: SurfaceTemperature
HeatFlow.description: Average Surface Ground Temperature at site based on shallow drilling (~10 m) or the average annual air temperature for the past decade.

HeatFlow.name: BHT
HeatFlow.description: Bottom Hole Temperature or Maximum Temperature from drilling log header of oil/gas well or well with only the log header available. Report temperatures in either degrees Fahrenheit or Celsius. Use same units throughout this document.

HeatFlow.name: BHTCorrectedValue
HeatFlow.description: Bottom Hole Temperature value corrected for drilling fluid influence on measurement. Estimate of an in situ value.

HeatFlow.name: BHTCorrectionType
HeatFlow.description: Method used to correct the BHT to what is estimated as an in situ value, e.g., Harrison, Förster, Horner, etc.

HeatFlow.name: EqLog_MeasurementDate
HeatFlow.description: Equilibrium Log Date for the record (date on which observation, measurement or test was made or specimen was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

HeatFlow.name: EqLog_TotalDepth
HeatFlow.description: Temperature Log or MRT (Maximum Reading Thermometer) total depth measured.

HeatFlow.name: EqLogTemperatureTop
HeatFlow.description: Shallowest depth of a measured hole temperature.

HeatFlow.name: EqLogTemperatureMax
HeatFlow.description: Hottest measured hole temperature.

HeatFlow.name: EqLogTemperatureBottom
HeatFlow.description: Deepest depth of measured hole temperature.

HeatFlow.name: SiteHeatFlow
HeatFlow.description: Highest confidence site value for heat flow based on all available intervals, corrections, quality confidence, etc. Value used for Heat Flow maps. (preferred units are mW/m2).

HeatFlow.name: SiteValueMethod
HeatFlow.description: Text description of method used to determine site values - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check. Single value, Mean Average, average after removal of specific 'outlier' interval values, etc.

HeatFlow.name: Intervals
HeatFlow.description: Number of interval measurements within this well. Default is 1.

HeatFlow.name: IntervalTopDepth
HeatFlow.description: Depth to the top of the interval being tested.

HeatFlow.name: IntervalBottomDepth
HeatFlow.description: Depth to the bottom of the interval being tested.

HeatFlow.name: ThermalConductivityUnits
HeatFlow.description: Units used for thermal conductivity value. Preferred units are Watt per meter per Kelvin (W m-1/K-1).

HeatFlow.name: IntervalThermalConductivity
HeatFlow.description: Laboratory measurement or estimated in situ rock thermal conductivity value for the depth interval. If 'intervals' = 1 (default) this value should be identical to SiteThermalConductivity.

HeatFlow.name: SE_Conductivity
HeatFlow.description: Standard Error for Conductivity Value.

HeatFlow.name: ConductivitySampleType
HeatFlow.description: Rock Cuttings, Core, Estimate, Cross-Section Name, Reference Name, Log Type, etc. When known, include Type and reference, e.g., Cross-Section: COSUNA CSR29; Estimate based on USGS Valley Fill value.

HeatFlow.name: ConductivityNumSamples
HeatFlow.description: Number of conductivity samples run to get measurement value.

HeatFlow.name: ConductivityMeasuredURI
HeatFlow.description: Related information on Conductivity template; give link information. Unique identifier for this observation. This is the identifier (Uniform Resource Identifier) that will be used to cross-reference data, samples, and other observations to the observation represented by this record. Best practice is to define an http URI that will dereference to a normative description of the observation. USGIN URI's may be redirected to any URL using the http://resources.usgin.org redirector; contact the USGIN development team at AZGS for instructions.

HeatFlow.name: GradientUnits
HeatFlow.description: °C/km (preferred) or °C/m or °F/100ft or °F/ft.  Note: degrees Celsius per kilometer (°C/km) is equivalent to milliwatts Kelvin per meter (mKm⁻1).

HeatFlow.name: IntervalUncorrectedGradient
HeatFlow.description: Gradient determined from initial temperatures for interval depth.

HeatFlow.name: SE_UncorrectedGradient
HeatFlow.description: Standard Error for Uncorrected Gradient Value; this can also be used for comments on gradient calculation.

HeatFlow.name: IntervalCorrectedGradient
HeatFlow.description: Thermal gradient measurement for the depth interval with corrected temperature and terrain corrections applied.

HeatFlow.name: SE_CorrectedGradient
HeatFlow.description: Standard Error for Corrected Gradient Value; this can also be used for comments on gradient calculation.

HeatFlow.name: IntervalCorrectedGradientMethod
HeatFlow.description: How correction was determined: "2-D Terrain" or "3-D Terrain" or "Corrected BHT" or "Climate" or "Hydrology" or "other". Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

HeatFlow.name: HeatFlowUnits
HeatFlow.description: Units used for heat flow values. Preferred units are milliWatts per meter squared (mW/m2).

HeatFlow.name: IntervalUncorrectedHeatFlow
HeatFlow.description: Uncorrected heat flow value for the depth interval. Based on thermal conductivity and uncorrected gradient.

HeatFlow.name: SE_UncorrectedHeatFlow
HeatFlow.description: Standard Error for Heat Flow Value.

HeatFlow.name: IntervalCorrectedHeatFlow
HeatFlow.description: Calculated or estimated corrected heat flow value based on corrected gradient and thermal conductivity. If 'Intervals' = 1 (default) this value will be identical to SiteHeatFlow. Possible to have only heat flow value from publication without gradient and conductivity information.

HeatFlow.name: SE_CorrectedHeatFlow
HeatFlow.description: Standard Error for Corrected Heat Flow Value. Free text to allow flexibility.

HeatFlow.name: IntervalHF_QualityCode
HeatFlow.description: Quality Code to indicate confidence of the heat flow value for well. When there is more than one well interval, add Heat Flow Quality to the primary interval. For Equilibrium Logs: A - High Quality Data: Deeper than 100 meters with at least a 50 meter linear gradient with corrections applied; B - Medium Quality Data: Deeper than 50 meters with gradient corrections applied; C - Poor Quality Data: Shallow; Isothermal; D - Use for background information but not mapping; G - Geothermal System: too high a value for regional maps; X - data accuracy low but want site recorded; For BHT Data: BHT-C: Many wells nearby with similar values; BHT-X: Single data source with no method to confirm accuracy of temperature or unreliable conductivity values. Other defined codes may be added.

HeatFlow.name: HF_QualityStatisticsMethod
HeatFlow.description: Method for determining the assigned Quality for heat flow values, e.g., Bullard Plot, Area Statistics, or Quality Code. Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

HeatFlow.name: HeatGenerationUnits
HeatFlow.description: Units for Heat Generation. Preferred units are muWatts per meter cubed (μW/m3).

HeatFlow.name: HeatGeneration
HeatFlow.description: Calculated value(s) from K, U, Th for an interval or for a drill hole.

HeatFlow.name: HG_NumberSamples
HeatFlow.description: Number of Heat production samples used to determine the Heat Generation value.

HeatFlow.name: WaterTableTop
HeatFlow.description: Depth for Top of Water Table based on log information. Depth units must be consistent with units stated above.

HeatFlow.name: WaterTableTemperature
HeatFlow.description: Measured, calculated or inferred value from equilibrium temperature logging. Units must be consistent with temperature units above.

HeatFlow.name: LithologyInformation
HeatFlow.description: Description of the lithology of surface geology or geologic column for well interval, e.g. arkose, granite, limestone, sandstone, schist. Recommend using CGI simple lithology vocabulary (see tab in this workbook). Use to account for EarthChem Material, EarthChem Type, EarthChem Composition, alluvium, 36-40': gravels; etc.

HeatFlow.name: FormationName
HeatFlow.description: Name of geologic unit for interval section or BHT value of well. Include hierarchy of names if the unit is part of a higher-rank geologic unit, e.g. Group name/Formation name, or Formation/Member, or Group/ Formation. Spell out unit names in full.

HeatFlow.name: Notes
HeatFlow.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about collection method, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

HeatFlow.name: Shape
HeatFlow.description: Added by GIS for WFS service; this element appears in the xml output, but is generated during service deployment from the latitude and longitude; therefore it doesn't appear in the template.

HeatFlow.name: OBJECTID
HeatFlow.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

HeatFlow.name: ObservationURI
HeatFlow.description: Unique identifier for this observation. This is the identifier (Uniform Resource Identifier) that will be used to cross-reference data, samples, and other observations to the observation represented by this record. Best practice is to define an http URI that will dereference to a normative description of the observation. USGIN URI's may be redirected to any URL using the http://resources.usgin.org redirector; contact the USGIN development team at AZGS for instructions.

HeatFlow.name: ObservationName
HeatFlow.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

HeatFlow.name: Label
HeatFlow.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as feature name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

HeatFlow.name: HeatFlowType
HeatFlow.description: Valid terms are SiteHF or IntervalHF Site = 'best' or 'highest confidence' value for the location. Interval = a unique combination of temperature, thermal conductivity, and heatflow for a location. If there is only one set of data (a single observation) for a location, use 'Site' in this field. If subsequent values become become available for a given location, the 'Site' value must be updated accordingly.

HeatFlow.name: RelatedHeatFlowIntervalsURI
HeatFlow.description: If Heat Flow value is based on multiple intervals, observationURIs are listed here. Unique identifier for this observation. This is the identifier (Uniform Resource Identifier) that will be used to cross-reference data, samples, and other observations to the observation represented by this record. Best practice is to define an http URI that will dereference to a normative description of the observation. USGIN URI's may be redirected to any URL using the http://resources.usgin.org redirector; contact the USGIN development team at AZGS for instructions.

HeatFlow.name: HeaderURI
HeatFlow.description: Unique identifier for the borehole indicated by this record. This identifier should identify the physical well, based on the API number if available. Otherwise, the URI should incorporate one of the OtherID values. Please contact the USGIN development team at AZGS for instructions.

HeatFlow.name: APINo
HeatFlow.description: API number for the the wellbore/borehole identified by the HeaderURI. If an API number is unavailable this field is empty. Usage of hyphens is optional, according to standard practice in each state. API number refers to the American Petroleum Institute number. Each oil, gas, or geothermal well drilled in the United States has a unique API number; this number identifies all boreholes or recompletions associated with the original wellbore. See the Data Valid Terms tab or http://www.spwla.org/technical/api-technical for more information about API numbering.

HeatFlow.name: WellName
HeatFlow.description: Human-intelligible name by which the feature  is known. Convention for wellName is: Name = Operator + Well No. + Lease Owner. A well may consist of multiple boreholes (wellbores). If these are distinguished by different records in this table, they should have the same well names, but distinct BoreholeNames, and at least one identifier (APINo or OtherID) that is unique to the borehole.

HeatFlow.name: OtherID
HeatFlow.description: Alternative identifier(s) for the feature. 'Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe '|' character. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the prefix would be azgs: and the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

HeatFlow.name: Owner
HeatFlow.description: Companies, individuals, or other entities who own the property. Separate multiple with a pipe '|' character.

HeatFlow.name: LeaseName
HeatFlow.description: Name of lease; usually incorporates property owner.

HeatFlow.name: Field
HeatFlow.description: Name of the field in which the borehole is located. If multiple names are or have been used for the field, separate values with a pipe '|' character.

HeatFlow.name: County
HeatFlow.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

HeatFlow.name: State
HeatFlow.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

HeatFlow.name: LatDegree
HeatFlow.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature using WGS1984; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

HeatFlow.name: LongDegree
HeatFlow.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature using WGS1984; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

HeatFlow.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
HeatFlow.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

HeatFlow.name: PLSS_Meridians
HeatFlow.description: List north-south baseline and east-west meridian that Townships and Ranges are referenced to.

HeatFlow.name: Township
HeatFlow.description: Township in PLSS grid, relative to reported baseline. Formatting and punctuation should be consistent for all locations referenced to the same baseline and meridian. Recommend adding leading '0's so that all number strings are the same length (typically 2 or occasionally 3 digits). Examples 01N, 112S, 001N.

HeatFlow.name: Range
HeatFlow.description: Range in PLSS grid, relative to reported meridian. Formatting and punctuation should be consistent for all locations referenced to the same baseline meridian. See instructions on TWP field.

HeatFlow.name: Section_
HeatFlow.description: PLSS section number. Must be numeric or null. Some surveys include half sections indicated by a 'nn.5' designation, where n indicates a number.

HeatFlow.name: SectionPart
HeatFlow.description: Subdivision of a PLSS section.

HeatFlow.name: TectonicProvince
HeatFlow.description: Tectonic division of a region based on geology.

HeatFlow.name: OtherLocationName
HeatFlow.description: Names of geographic features associated with the site that will be useful as search criteria to locate the information for this site. If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, separate these identifiers with the pipe character '|'.

HeatFlow.name: PublicationSource
HeatFlow.description: Most recent source of the Heat Flow Value, e.g., journal, book, report, internet site, etc. Consists of 2 parts: Primary Author's last name, Year Published; if available include the Publication Unique ID. If unpublished, include owner/location of data (e.g., unpublished SMU 2011).

HeatFlow.name: AdditionalSources
HeatFlow.description: For more than one publication, list older references here. List data sources for other parameters, e. g., conductivity, climate data, surface temperature, cross-sections, etc; text description of observation lineage / provenance.

HeatFlow.name: RelatedResource
HeatFlow.description: This may be one to many http links to resources (logs, pictures or other documents if available online. Should be an http:// address (URL)) related to the observation described in each record. Delimit multiple values with the pipe '|' character.

HeatFlow.name: WellType
HeatFlow.description: Type of well that contains the borehole.

HeatFlow.name: WellDrillDate
HeatFlow.description: Date of well activity entered in WellDrillDateType field. Specify day, month and year; Will be displayed using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,').All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm.

HeatFlow.name: WellDrillDateType
HeatFlow.description: Provide what the 'drill date' represents. e.g. Spud/Start, Completion, Well Header date, etc.

HeatFlow.name: Elevation
HeatFlow.description: Elevation of the well. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL).

HeatFlow.name: ElevationType
HeatFlow.description: Specify where value in elevation field refers to. Valid terms include: GL-Ground level, KB - Kelly bushing, DF - Derrick floor, well collar, other, unknown.

HeatFlow.name: DepthUnits
HeatFlow.description: Units used to report all elevation and depth information.

HeatFlow.name: DrillerTotalDepth
HeatFlow.description: Length of borehole identified by the HeaderURI, from borehole origin to bottom of borehole.

HeatFlow.name: TimeSinceCirculation
HeatFlow.description: The amount of time since circulation in well stopped before temperature was taken. Stated on Well Log Header.

HeatFlow.name: TemperatureUnits
HeatFlow.description: Report temperatures in degrees Fahrenheit or Celsius. Use same units throughout this document.

HeatFlow.name: TemperatureMeasureType
HeatFlow.description: Method used to collect temperatures. Valid terms include: BHT (Bottom Hole Temperature from well log header), EQ (Equilibrium or precision data collected using temperature logging gear), MRT (Maximum Reading Thermometers), PL (from Pressure Log), Inferred (e.g. from Heat Production), Other, or Unknown.

HeatFlow.name: SurfaceTemperature
HeatFlow.description: Average Surface Ground Temperature at site based on shallow drilling (~10 m) or the average annual air temperature for the past decade.

HeatFlow.name: BHT
HeatFlow.description: Bottom Hole Temperature or Maximum Temperature from drilling log header of oil/gas well or well with only the log header available. Report temperatures in either degrees Fahrenheit or Celsius. Use same units throughout this document.

HeatFlow.name: BHTCorrectedValue
HeatFlow.description: Bottom Hole Temperature value corrected for drilling fluid influence on measurement. Estimate of an in situ value.

HeatFlow.name: BHTCorrectionType
HeatFlow.description: Method used to correct the BHT to what is estimated as an in situ value, e.g., Harrison, Förster, Horner, etc.

HeatFlow.name: EqLog_MeasurementDate
HeatFlow.description: Equilibrium Log Date for the record (date on which observation, measurement or test was made or specimen was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

HeatFlow.name: EqLog_TotalDepth
HeatFlow.description: Temperature Log or MRT (Maximum Reading Thermometer) total depth measured.

HeatFlow.name: EqLogTemperatureTop
HeatFlow.description: Shallowest depth of a measured hole temperature.

HeatFlow.name: EqLogTemperatureMax
HeatFlow.description: Hottest measured hole temperature.

HeatFlow.name: EqLogTemperatureBottom
HeatFlow.description: Deepest depth of measured hole temperature.

HeatFlow.name: SiteHeatFlow
HeatFlow.description: Highest confidence site value for heat flow based on all available intervals, corrections, quality confidence, etc. Value used for Heat Flow maps. (preferred units are mW/m2).

HeatFlow.name: SiteValueMethod
HeatFlow.description: Text description of method used to determine site values - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check. Single value, Mean Average, average after removal of specific 'outlier' interval values, etc.

HeatFlow.name: Intervals
HeatFlow.description: Number of interval measurements within this well. Default is 1.

HeatFlow.name: IntervalTopDepth
HeatFlow.description: Depth to the top of the interval being tested.

HeatFlow.name: IntervalBottomDepth
HeatFlow.description: Depth to the bottom of the interval being tested.

HeatFlow.name: ThermalConductivityUnits
HeatFlow.description: Units used for thermal conductivity value. Preferred units are Watt per meter per Kelvin (W m-1/K-1).

HeatFlow.name: IntervalThermalConductivity
HeatFlow.description: Laboratory measurement or estimated in situ rock thermal conductivity value for the depth interval. If 'intervals' = 1 (default) this value should be identical to SiteThermalConductivity.

HeatFlow.name: SE_Conductivity
HeatFlow.description: Standard Error for Conductivity Value.

HeatFlow.name: ConductivitySampleType
HeatFlow.description: Rock Cuttings, Core, Estimate, Cross-Section Name, Reference Name, Log Type, etc. When known, include Type and reference, e.g., Cross-Section: COSUNA CSR29; Estimate based on USGS Valley Fill value.

HeatFlow.name: ConductivityNumSamples
HeatFlow.description: Number of conductivity samples run to get measurement value.

HeatFlow.name: ConductivityMeasuredURI
HeatFlow.description: Related information on Conductivity template; give link information. Unique identifier for this observation. This is the identifier (Uniform Resource Identifier) that will be used to cross-reference data, samples, and other observations to the observation represented by this record. Best practice is to define an http URI that will dereference to a normative description of the observation. USGIN URI's may be redirected to any URL using the http://resources.usgin.org redirector; contact the USGIN development team at AZGS for instructions.

HeatFlow.name: GradientUnits
HeatFlow.description: °C/km (preferred) or °C/m or °F/100ft or °F/ft.  Note: degrees Celsius per kilometer (°C/km) is equivalent to milliwatts Kelvin per meter (mKm⁻1).

HeatFlow.name: IntervalUncorrectedGradient
HeatFlow.description: Gradient determined from initial temperatures for interval depth.

HeatFlow.name: SE_UncorrectedGradient
HeatFlow.description: Standard Error for Uncorrected Gradient Value; this can also be used for comments on gradient calculation.

HeatFlow.name: IntervalCorrectedGradient
HeatFlow.description: Thermal gradient measurement for the depth interval with corrected temperature and terrain corrections applied.

HeatFlow.name: SE_CorrectedGradient
HeatFlow.description: Standard Error for Corrected Gradient Value; this can also be used for comments on gradient calculation.

HeatFlow.name: IntervalCorrectedGradientMethod
HeatFlow.description: How correction was determined: "2-D Terrain" or "3-D Terrain" or "Corrected BHT" or "Climate" or "Hydrology" or "other". Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

HeatFlow.name: HeatFlowUnits
HeatFlow.description: Units used for heat flow values. Preferred units are milliWatts per meter squared (mW/m2).

HeatFlow.name: IntervalUncorrectedHeatFlow
HeatFlow.description: Uncorrected heat flow value for the depth interval. Based on thermal conductivity and uncorrected gradient.

HeatFlow.name: SE_UncorrectedHeatFlow
HeatFlow.description: Standard Error for Heat Flow Value.

HeatFlow.name: IntervalCorrectedHeatFlow
HeatFlow.description: Calculated or estimated corrected heat flow value based on corrected gradient and thermal conductivity. If 'Intervals' = 1 (default) this value will be identical to SiteHeatFlow. Possible to have only heat flow value from publication without gradient and conductivity information.

HeatFlow.name: SE_CorrectedHeatFlow
HeatFlow.description: Standard Error for Corrected Heat Flow Value. Free text to allow flexibility.

HeatFlow.name: IntervalHF_QualityCode
HeatFlow.description: Quality Code to indicate confidence of the heat flow value for well. When there is more than one well interval, add Heat Flow Quality to the primary interval. For Equilibrium Logs: A - High Quality Data: Deeper than 100 meters with at least a 50 meter linear gradient with corrections applied; B - Medium Quality Data: Deeper than 50 meters with gradient corrections applied; C - Poor Quality Data: Shallow; Isothermal; D - Use for background information but not mapping; G - Geothermal System: too high a value for regional maps; X - data accuracy low but want site recorded; For BHT Data: BHT-C: Many wells nearby with similar values; BHT-X: Single data source with no method to confirm accuracy of temperature or unreliable conductivity values. Other defined codes may be added.

HeatFlow.name: HF_QualityStatisticsMethod
HeatFlow.description: Method for determining the assigned Quality for heat flow values, e.g., Bullard Plot, Area Statistics, or Quality Code. Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

HeatFlow.name: HeatGenerationUnits
HeatFlow.description: Units for Heat Generation. Preferred units are muWatts per meter cubed (μW/m3).

HeatFlow.name: HeatGeneration
HeatFlow.description: Calculated value(s) from K, U, Th for an interval or for a drill hole.

HeatFlow.name: HG_NumberSamples
HeatFlow.description: Number of Heat production samples used to determine the Heat Generation value.

HeatFlow.name: WaterTableTop
HeatFlow.description: Depth for Top of Water Table based on log information. Depth units must be consistent with units stated above.

HeatFlow.name: WaterTableTemperature
HeatFlow.description: Measured, calculated or inferred value from equilibrium temperature logging. Units must be consistent with temperature units above.

HeatFlow.name: LithologyInformation
HeatFlow.description: Description of the lithology of surface geology or geologic column for well interval, e.g. arkose, granite, limestone, sandstone, schist. Recommend using CGI simple lithology vocabulary (see tab in this workbook). Use to account for EarthChem Material, EarthChem Type, EarthChem Composition, alluvium, 36-40': gravels; etc.

HeatFlow.name: FormationName
HeatFlow.description: Name of geologic unit for interval section or BHT value of well. Include hierarchy of names if the unit is part of a higher-rank geologic unit, e.g. Group name/Formation name, or Formation/Member, or Group/ Formation. Spell out unit names in full.

HeatFlow.name: Notes
HeatFlow.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about collection method, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

HeatFlow.name: Shape
HeatFlow.description: Added by GIS for WFS service; this element appears in the xml output, but is generated during service deployment from the latitude and longitude; therefore it doesn't appear in the template.

label: heatflow

status:
Version 0.6 schema

Version 0.6 has been submitted for NGDS technical team review, and the Excel workbook has been adopted for NGDS partner projects and posted on the NGDS web site resources/public documents section.
description: This spreadsheet indicates the content requested for features representing heat pump facility locations. Design is focused on sites/facilities portrayed as geospatial points with associated facility type, use application, and operational date. Heat Pump facility data for the geothermal data system is intended as a tool to identify information related to facility construction and location, thus the content model may not include detailed information. Such information should be accessed by including related resource links. As such, data is intended to be restricted to records for existing heat pump facilities.
title: Heat Pump Facility
discussion: This template defines the content model for a service that delivers heat pump facility features. Many of these will be standard map location and IDs, but other information may be delivered. Much of the variation will concern system information such as system type and citations. The heat pump facility content model is designed to be used for data compilation from permits, databases, and field data. The content model presented here is intended to present key information necessary to query a heat pump facility feature service and to evaluate site specific information.

HeatPumpFacility.name: OBJECTID
HeatPumpFacility.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

HeatPumpFacility.name: FacilityURI
HeatPumpFacility.description: Unique identifier that specifies the facility. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature.

HeatPumpFacility.name: FacilityName
HeatPumpFacility.description: Common or human-readable name by which the facility is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

HeatPumpFacility.name: Label
HeatPumpFacility.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as feature name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

HeatPumpFacility.name: OtherID
HeatPumpFacility.description: Alternative identifier(s) for the feature. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe '|' character. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the prefix would be azgs: and the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

HeatPumpFacility.name: FacilityOwner
HeatPumpFacility.description: Companies, individuals, or other entities who own the property. Separate multiple with a pipe '|' character.

HeatPumpFacility.name: Notes
HeatPumpFacility.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about collection method, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

HeatPumpFacility.name: FacilityStatus
HeatPumpFacility.description: Status of the feature at the time indicated in the StatusDate element. If unknown enter "unknown" in the field.

HeatPumpFacility.name: StatusDate
HeatPumpFacility.description: The status of the feature can change from time to time, thus it is useful to know the date on which a given status was reported. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

HeatPumpFacility.name: SystemType
HeatPumpFacility.description: Physical type of the system.

HeatPumpFacility.name: HeatExchangeSystem
HeatPumpFacility.description: Name of compound used to facilitate heat exchange. (Glycol, CO2, Water, Ethylene).

HeatPumpFacility.name: HVAC_specs
HeatPumpFacility.description: Additional specifications of the HVAC system with respect to the physical installation.

HeatPumpFacility.name: DateInstalled
HeatPumpFacility.description: Date facility installation was completed. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

HeatPumpFacility.name: HeatApplication
HeatPumpFacility.description: Statement for how heat is being used. Should come from controlled vocabulary.

HeatPumpFacility.name: County
HeatPumpFacility.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

HeatPumpFacility.name: State
HeatPumpFacility.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

HeatPumpFacility.name: PLSS_Meridians
HeatPumpFacility.description: List north-south baseline and east-west meridian that Townships and Ranges are referenced to.

HeatPumpFacility.name: Township
HeatPumpFacility.description: Township in PLSS grid, relative to reported baseline. Formatting and punctuation should be consistent for all locations referenced to the same baseline and meridian. Recommend adding leading '0's so that all number strings are the same length (typically 2 or occasionally 3 digits). Examples 01N, 112S, 001 N.

HeatPumpFacility.name: Range
HeatPumpFacility.description: Range in PLSS grid, relative to reported meridian. Formatting and punctuation should be consistent for all locations referenced to the same baseline meridian. See instructions on TWP field.

HeatPumpFacility.name: Section_
HeatPumpFacility.description: PLSS section number. Must be numeric or null. Some surveys include half sections indicated by a 'nn.5' designation, where n indicates a number.

HeatPumpFacility.name: SectionPart
HeatPumpFacility.description: Subdivision of a PLSS section.

HeatPumpFacility.name: OtherLocationInformation
HeatPumpFacility.description: Names of geographic features associated with the site that will be useful as search criteria to locate the information for this site. If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'.

HeatPumpFacility.name: UTM_E
HeatPumpFacility.description: UTM easting coordinate as decimal number.

HeatPumpFacility.name: UTM_N
HeatPumpFacility.description: UTM northing coordinate as decimal number.

HeatPumpFacility.name: UTMDatumZone
HeatPumpFacility.description: The datum and UTM zone for the reported coordinates. Datum for most locations should be NAD27 or NAD83.

HeatPumpFacility.name: LatDegree
HeatPumpFacility.description: Latitude coordinate for facility site center point; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

HeatPumpFacility.name: LongDegree
HeatPumpFacility.description: Longitude coordinate for facility site center point; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

HeatPumpFacility.name: SRS
HeatPumpFacility.description: The spatial reference system. It is recommended that an EPSG code be used to identify the SRS used to specify the location. If an EPSG code is used, identify it as such with the prefix 'EPSG:' For common EPSG codes, see the Data Valid Terms tab. EPSG:4326 is the identifier for WGS84, and should be the text in this field.

HeatPumpFacility.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
HeatPumpFacility.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g., 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

HeatPumpFacility.name: Driller
HeatPumpFacility.description: Name of contractor that drilled the borehole(s) for the Heat Pump facility.

HeatPumpFacility.name: NumberOfWells
HeatPumpFacility.description: Enter the number of wells for the completed system.

HeatPumpFacility.name: SpacingAvg_ft
HeatPumpFacility.description: The average distance between boreholes in feet.

HeatPumpFacility.name: SpudDate
HeatPumpFacility.description: Date for the record: date on which observation, measurement or test was made or specimen was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

HeatPumpFacility.name: EndedDrillingDate
HeatPumpFacility.description: Date on which drilling of the well bore ended. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1'. If year is unknown, enter 1900. All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm. This is intended as a searching aid.

HeatPumpFacility.name: Permit
HeatPumpFacility.description: Permit(s) assigned to the facility; if identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe '|' character.

HeatPumpFacility.name: ElevationGL
HeatPumpFacility.description: Elevation, in meters, at ground level for the feature. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL). If elevation varies, use the average elevation.

HeatPumpFacility.name: DrillerTotalDepth_ft
HeatPumpFacility.description: Length of borehole from borehole origin to bottom of borehole. If there are multiple wells, use the depth of the deepest well.

HeatPumpFacility.name: HoleDiameter_in
HeatPumpFacility.description: Bit diameter at the origin of the borehole, reported in inches in decimal format.

HeatPumpFacility.name: CasingType
HeatPumpFacility.description: Type of casing used in the borehole, for example "steel" or "plastic".

HeatPumpFacility.name: CasingDiameter_in
HeatPumpFacility.description: Internal (ID) or external diameter (ED) should be noted. Units must be same as those used to report bit diameter (Diameter units column). Note that if there are different casing types over different intervals in the well bore, these should be noted in tuples delimited by the pipe character '|' as follows: {top-bottom1, diameter1, xD1 | top-bottom2, diameter2, xD2}.

HeatPumpFacility.name: CasingDepth_ft
HeatPumpFacility.description: Bottom of cased interval of the borehole as reported by the driller..

HeatPumpFacility.name: DepthToWater_ft
HeatPumpFacility.description: Depth to groundwater in feet.

HeatPumpFacility.name: Depth_ft
HeatPumpFacility.description: Depth of the trench that is part of the system identified by the FacilityURI.

HeatPumpFacility.name: NumberOfTrenches
HeatPumpFacility.description: The number of trenches that are part of the system identified by the FacilityURI.

HeatPumpFacility.name: FluidType
HeatPumpFacility.description: Please use Commodity of Interest vocabulary; use multiple records if multiple fluids produced or injected during reported interval.

HeatPumpFacility.name: PipeDiameter_in
HeatPumpFacility.description: Diameter of the pipe, in decimal inches, used to convey the fluid within the system.

HeatPumpFacility.name: PipeMaterial
HeatPumpFacility.description: Material of the pipe used to convey the fluids.

HeatPumpFacility.name: PipeTotalLength_ft
HeatPumpFacility.description: Total length of the pipe in the system in decimal feet.

HeatPumpFacility.name: LithologyDescription
HeatPumpFacility.description: Description of the lithology of surface geology or geologic column for well interval, e.g. granite, sandstone, limestone, arkose, schist. Recommend using CGI simple lithology vocabulary (see tab in this workbook). Use to account for EarthChem Material, EarthChem Type, EarthChem Composition.d alluvium, 36-40': gravels; etc.

HeatPumpFacility.name: GeologicFormation
HeatPumpFacility.description: Name of geologic unit that was encountered during drilling or trenching. Include hierarchy of names if the unit is part of a higher-rank geologic unit, e.g. Group name/Formation name, or Formation/Member, or Group/ Formation. Spell out unit names in full.

HeatPumpFacility.name: FacilityContact
HeatPumpFacility.description: Person, organization, or position name for information about the facility.

HeatPumpFacility.name: PostalAddress
HeatPumpFacility.description: Postal address for facility. Street, City, State.

HeatPumpFacility.name: Zip
HeatPumpFacility.description: Zip code for facility; may be used for some geolocation information.

HeatPumpFacility.name: Phone
HeatPumpFacility.description: Telephone number to contact party connected with facility.

HeatPumpFacility.name: EMailAddress
HeatPumpFacility.description: E-mail address to contact party connected with facility.

HeatPumpFacility.name: Source
HeatPumpFacility.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining this feature or record; may be author-date type citation, well log, report, data files etc., but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe '|' character.

HeatPumpFacility.name: MetadataURI
HeatPumpFacility.description: URI identifying (and ideally dereferencing to get) a full formal metadata record for the observation report. A time series of observations may all reference the same metadata record that provides contact information and details on procedure, etc.

HeatPumpFacility.name: UpdateTimeStamp
HeatPumpFacility.description: Date of last time line of data was updated or corrected by the service provider.(Format: 2012-06-22T00:00).

HeatPumpFacility.name: Shape
HeatPumpFacility.description: Added by GIS for WFS service; this element appears in the xml output, but is generated during service deployment from the latitude and longitude, therefore it doesn't appear in the template.

label: HeatPumpFacility

status: Version 1.0 has been approved for use by the NGDS working group.
description: This information exchange is an aid for compiling data for delivery as hydraulic property observations for the National Geothermal Data System. The HydraulicPropertyObservation worksheet specifies content elements for an interchange format for data obtained from boreholes.  Fields in that spreadsheet  will become XML elements in interchange documents for WFS simple features/geothermal data web services. Typically hydraulic properties are collected during pump testing and/or laboratory analysis, and this information will be provided through a hydraulic property observation service.  The HeaderURI for a particular borehole (well for simple wells) is the cross-referencing link (foreign key) used to associate the header record, well logs, temperature measurements, and other information from a particular borehole.
title: Hydraulic Properties

HydraulicProperty.name: OBJECTID
HydraulicProperty.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

HydraulicProperty.name: ObservationURI
HydraulicProperty.description: Unique identifier for this observation. This is the identifier (Uniform Resource Identifier) that will be used to cross-reference data, samples, and other observations to the observation represented by this record. Best practice is to define an http URI that will dereference to a normative description of the observation. USGIN URI's may be redirected to any URL using the http://resources.usgin.org redirector; contact the USGIN development team at AZGS for instructions.

HydraulicProperty.name: ObservationName
HydraulicProperty.description: The human-intelligible name for the observation; may be a concatenation of observation type and feature name.

HydraulicProperty.name: WellType
HydraulicProperty.description: Type of well that contains the borehole identified by the HeaderURI, at the time indicated in the StatusDate element.

HydraulicProperty.name: HeaderURI
HydraulicProperty.description: Unique identifier for the borehole indicated by this record. This identifier should identify the physical well, based on the API number if available. Otherwise, the URI should incorporate one of the OtherID values. Please contact the USGIN development team at AZGS for instructions.

HydraulicProperty.name: WellName
HydraulicProperty.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

HydraulicProperty.name: OtherID
HydraulicProperty.description: Alternative identifier(s) for the feature. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe '|' character. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the prefix would be azgs: and the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

HydraulicProperty.name: County
HydraulicProperty.description: County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

HydraulicProperty.name: State
HydraulicProperty.description: State without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

HydraulicProperty.name: LatDegreeWGS84
HydraulicProperty.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

HydraulicProperty.name: LongDegreeWGS84
HydraulicProperty.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

HydraulicProperty.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
HydraulicProperty.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g., 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

HydraulicProperty.name: DepthTopInterval_ft
HydraulicProperty.description: Depth to the top of the interval, reported in feet from borehole origin.

HydraulicProperty.name: DepthBottomInterval_ft
HydraulicProperty.description: Depth to the bottom of the interval, reported in feet from borehole origin.

HydraulicProperty.name: RockType
HydraulicProperty.description: Free text name for lithology category of sample, e.g. biotite-hornblende granite, lithofeldspathic sandstone, calcareous arkose, biotite schist.

HydraulicProperty.name: Lithology
HydraulicProperty.description: Description of the lithology of surface geology or geologic column for well interval, e.g. granite, sandstone, limestone, arkose, schist. Recommend using CGI simple lithology vocabulary (see tab in this workbook). Use to account for EarthChem Material, EarthChem Type, EarthChem Composition, alluvium, 36-40': gravels; etc.

HydraulicProperty.name: GeologicUnitName
HydraulicProperty.description: Name of geologic unit that was sampled. Include hierarchy of names if the unit is part of a higher-rank geologic unit, e.g. Group name/Formation name, or Formation/Member, or Group/ Formation. Spell out unit names in full.

HydraulicProperty.name: VerticalConductivity_ft_day
HydraulicProperty.description: Physical property that quantitatively describes the ability of a fluid to move vertically through the pore spaces and/or fractures in a material. Report Conductivity values in ft/day.

HydraulicProperty.name: HorizontalConductivity_ft_day
HydraulicProperty.description: Physical property that quantitatively describes the ability of a fluid to move horizontally through the pore spaces and/or fractures in a material. Report Conductivity values in ft/day.

HydraulicProperty.name: SpecificStorage
HydraulicProperty.description: The volume of water an aquifer releases from or takes into storage per unit surface area of the aquifer per unit change in head.

HydraulicProperty.name: UnitsStorage
HydraulicProperty.description: Units for the reported specific storage. (1/[length]).

HydraulicProperty.name: Permeability
HydraulicProperty.description: The property or capacity of a porous rock, sediment, or soil for transmitting a fluid; it is a measure of the relative ease of fluid flow under unequal pressure.

HydraulicProperty.name: UnitsPermeability
HydraulicProperty.description: Units for the reported permability. The SI unit for permeability is m^2. A practical unit for permeability is the darcy (D), or more commonly the millidarcy (mD) (1 darcy \approx10−12/m^2).

HydraulicProperty.name: SpecificYield_percent
HydraulicProperty.description: The ratio of the volume of water that a given mass of saturated rock or soil will yield by gravity to the volume of that mass.

HydraulicProperty.name: Transmissivity
HydraulicProperty.description: The transmissivity is a measure of how much water can be transmitted horizontally, such as to a pumping well. Transmissivity is directly proportional to horizontal hydraulic conductivity and thickness of the transmitting layer.

HydraulicProperty.name: Transmissivity_units
HydraulicProperty.description: Units are (length)^2/Time.

HydraulicProperty.name: EffectivePorosity
HydraulicProperty.description: The percentage of pore volume or void space, or that volume within rock that can contain fluids.

HydraulicProperty.name: ObservationMethod
HydraulicProperty.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

HydraulicProperty.name: RelatedResource
HydraulicProperty.description: This may be one to many http links to resources (logs, pictures or other documents if available online. Should be an http:// address (URL)) related to the observation described in each record. Delimit multiple values with the pipe '|' character.

HydraulicProperty.name: Source
HydraulicProperty.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining this feature or record; may be author-date type citation, well log, report, data files etc., but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe '|' character.

status: Version 0.11 is the first released, public version of this content model.
description:
This information exchange documents and describes observations made by various processes of recovering minerals (specifically REEs) from geothermal brines. Two data tabs are included in this content model spreadsheet; Experiment alData is for capturing the variables to describe/evaluate REE removal and capturing the variables influencing removal and describing removal media; ScaledProcessAndEconomics is for describing the variables in the removal (“reactor”) technique, the ability of the media to be re-used, and the techno-economic and process economics. This information exchange is constructed to record observations of REE extraction processes and can be used to compare the efficacy of those processes. For the data derived from any experiment (REE and other elements, minerals, and metals values) see the BrinesRareEarths tab in the AqueousChemisty information exchange at https://github.com/usgin-models/AqueousChemistry.
If any fields need to be added to this content model to capture necessary and relevant data, please add those additional fields after the "End" field in any data tab of this spreadsheet (which will be the very last fields in any spreadsheet). No other modifications to the spreadsheet fields is permitted.
title: Mineral Recovery Brines

ExperimentalData.name: OBJECTID
ExperimentalData.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

ExperimentalData.name: RemovalSampleURI
ExperimentalData.description: A unique identifier for this observation.

ExperimentalData.name: Source
ExperimentalData.description:
Short text explanation of source of information defining feature; may be author-date type 
citation, but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe ('|') character.

ExperimentalData.name: RelatedResources
ExperimentalData.description:
Related document or data resource, preferably accessible online. If data is compiled in the USGIN Aq
ueousChemistry model, BrineRareEarths analyte suite, URIs in http link should be given here.

ExperimentalData.name: Notes
ExperimentalData.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about collection method, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

ExperimentalData.name: MetadataURI
ExperimentalData.description:
URI identifying (and ideally dereferencing to get) a full formal metadata record for the observation

information and details on procedure, etc.
