Isotopes.description: Age of a sample as described by the stratigraphic  era, period, etc. “Cretaceous”; “Upper Miocene”.

Isotopes.name: County
Isotopes.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

Isotopes.name: State
Isotopes.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

Isotopes.name: LatDegree
Isotopes.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

Isotopes.name: LongDegree
Isotopes.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

Isotopes.name: SRS
Isotopes.description: The spatial reference system. It is recommended that an EPSG code be used to identify the SRS used to specify the location.  If an EPSG code is used, identify it as such with the prefix 'EPSG:' For common EPSG codes, see the Data Valid Terms tab. EPSG:4326 is the identifier for WGS84, and should be the text in this field. EPSG stands for European Petroleum Survey Group. EPSSG codes can be dereferenced by putting the code in this URL (replace 4326) http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/4326/.

Isotopes.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
Isotopes.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

Isotopes.name: LocalityTerms
Isotopes.description: Additional information or more geographic names associated with sample collection location; if multiple names supplied, delimit with pipe '|' character, e.g. Arizona | La Paz County | Harquahala Mountains | Browns Canyon.

Isotopes.name: DatumElevation
Isotopes.description: The point of reference against which elevation measurements are made. Best practice: use mean sea level (MSL) as datum.

Isotopes.name: Elevation
Isotopes.description: Elevation at ground level the sample came from. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL).

Isotopes.name: ElevationUnits
Isotopes.description: Units used to report all elevation and depth information.

Isotopes.name: Citation
Isotopes.description: Free text citation, using some standard journal format, that identifies a publication in which this sample was defined.  For samples that are not described in publications, text description of where sample came from should include name of person or organization to contact to access sample.

Isotopes.name: Source
Isotopes.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining feature; may be author-date type citation, but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe ('|') character.

Isotopes.name: MetadataURI
Isotopes.description: URI identifying (and ideally dereferencing to get) a full formal metadata record for the observation report. A time series of observations may all reference the same metadata record that provides contact information and details on procedure, etc.

Isotopes.name: RelatedResource
Isotopes.description: This may be one to many http links to resources (logs, pictures or other documents if available online. Should be an http:// address (URL)) related to the observation described in each record. Delimit multiple values with the pipe '|' character.

Isotopes.name: AnalysisType
Isotopes.description: Type of analysis used to obtain the results in this record.

Isotopes.name: AnalysisDate
Isotopes.description: Date for the record (date on which measurement or test was made. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

Isotopes.name: Laboratory
Isotopes.description: If a Laboratory performed the analysis, include name and address here.

Isotopes.name: ProcedureSummary
Isotopes.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

Isotopes.name: UpdateTimeStamp
Isotopes.description: Date of last time line of data was updated or corrected by the service provider.(Format: 2012-06-22T00:00).

TraceElements.name: OBJECTID
TraceElements.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

TraceElements.name: AnalysisURI
TraceElements.description: A unique identifier for a discrete analysis of a specimen taken from a feature. The feature from which the specimen was taken will be identified by its own URI.

TraceElements.name: AnalysisName
TraceElements.description: The human-intelligible name of the analysis. May be a concatenation of analysis type, feature name, and specimen label. This element is specific, not generic; i.e., do not use generic terms such as "Analyte Analysis".

TraceElements.name: OtherAnalysisID
TraceElements.description: Alternative identifier(s) for this analysis. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe '|' character. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the prefix would be azgs: and the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

TraceElements.name: Notes
TraceElements.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about methods, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

TraceElements.name: DetectionLimitURI
TraceElements.description: Unique identifier that specifies the Limits of the test. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature. Unique identifier for each set of samples, each analyzed using the same method, technique and using the same equipment.

TraceElements.name: SamplingFeatureName
TraceElements.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

TraceElements.name: SamplingFeatureURI
TraceElements.description: Unique Identifier for the particular site (station) or well where the sample(s) came from. For wells, this might be the HeaderURI or API number used in other metadata files. If unavailable, state 'missing'. SamplingFeature is a concept that represents the feature that accesses the part of the Earth from which the sample came, e.g. outcrop, borehole, dredge haul.

TraceElements.name: SpecimenID
TraceElements.description: ID given to the specimen by the collector(s). Recommended practice: include a short abbreviation in a prefix indicating the authority or scope of the identifier (e.g. 'usgs:'); any prefixes should be explained in the dataset metadata.

TraceElements.name: OtherSpecimenID
TraceElements.description: Alternative identifier(s) for the feature. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

TraceElements.name: SpecimenURI
TraceElements.description: Unique identifier for sample; should include protocol prefix with known meaning, delimited by a ':' (colon), e.g. igsn:24623570 or http://resources.usgin.org/uri-gin/AZGS/sample/24623570.

TraceElements.name: ParentSampleURI
TraceElements.description: Identifier for a sample from which this specimen was sub-sampled. E.g. if a piece from a registered core is registered as a separate sample, this would be the identifier for the core.

TraceElements.name: Label
TraceElements.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as feature name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

TraceElements.name: SpecimenCollectionDate
TraceElements.description: Date on which specimen sample was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

TraceElements.name: SpecimenLabel
TraceElements.description: Short text string to identify/characterize the sample used in this observation; may include one or more sample names as provided by the sample collector or analyzing laboratory.

TraceElements.name: SpecimenDescription
TraceElements.description: Free text field for any additional observations or other information regarding the feature (size, weight, quality, lithology, locality, etc).

TraceElements.name: SampleCollectionMethod
TraceElements.description: Method used to collect specimen; may be hand sample, core or drill cuttings.

TraceElements.name: SpecimenType
TraceElements.description: Term to describe the type of specimen. Use term from list of Specimen types. If the specimen type collected is not present on this list, add the specimen type to the list in the example column.

TraceElements.name: SpecimenCollector
TraceElements.description: Free text specification of person, organization, affiliation, address, etc. for party that originally collected specimen. Include contact information if available.

TraceElements.name: MaterialClass
TraceElements.description: Category from simple material classification scheme e.g. rock, sediment, aqueous liquid, other liquid, gas, biological material.

TraceElements.name: LithologyTerms
TraceElements.description: Description of the lithology of surface geology or geologic column for well interval, e.g. arkose, granite, limestone, sandstone, schist. Recommend using CGI simple lithology vocabulary (see tab in this workbook). Use to account for EarthChem Material, EarthChem Type, EarthChem Composition, alluvium, 36-40': gravels; etc.

TraceElements.name: RockName
TraceElements.description: Free text name for lithology category of sample, e.g. biotite-hornblende granite, lithofeldspathic sandstone, calcareous arkose, biotite schist.

TraceElements.name: SampledGeologicUnit
TraceElements.description: Name of geologic unit that was sampled. Include hierarchy of names if the unit is part of a higher-rank geologic unit, e.g. Group name/Formation name, or Formation/Member, or Group/ Formation. Spell out unit names in full.

TraceElements.name: SampledGeologicUnitAge
TraceElements.description: Age of a sample as described by the stratigraphic  era, period, etc. “Cretaceous”; “Upper Miocene”.

TraceElements.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

StableIsotopes.description: Identifier for a sample from which this specimen was sub-sampled. E.g. if a piece from a registered core is registered as a separate sample, this would be the identifier for the core.

StableIsotopes.name: Label
StableIsotopes.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as feature name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

StableIsotopes.name: SpecimenCollectionDate
StableIsotopes.description: Date on which specimen sample was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

StableIsotopes.name: SpecimenLabel
StableIsotopes.description: Short text string to identify/characterize the sample used in this observation; may include one or more sample names as provided by the sample collector or analyzing laboratory.

StableIsotopes.name: SpecimenDescription
StableIsotopes.description: Free text field for any additional observations or other information regarding the feature (size, weight, quality, lithology, locality, etc).

StableIsotopes.name: SampleCollectionMethod
StableIsotopes.description: Method used to collect specimen; may be hand sample, core or drill cuttings.

StableIsotopes.name: SpecimenType
StableIsotopes.description: Term to describe the type of specimen. Use term from list of Specimen types. If the specimen type collected is not present on this list, add the specimen type to the list in the example column.

StableIsotopes.name: SpecimenCollector
StableIsotopes.description: Free text specification of person, organization, affiliation, address, etc. for party that originally collected specimen. Include contact information if available.

StableIsotopes.name: MaterialClass
StableIsotopes.description: Category from simple material classification scheme e.g. rock, sediment, aqueous liquid, other liquid, gas, biological material.

StableIsotopes.name: LithologyTerms
StableIsotopes.description: Description of the lithology of surface geology or geologic column for well interval, e.g. arkose, granite, limestone, sandstone, schist. Recommend using CGI simple lithology vocabulary (see tab in this workbook). Use to account for EarthChem Material, EarthChem Type, EarthChem Composition, alluvium, 36-40': gravels; etc.

StableIsotopes.name: RockName
StableIsotopes.description: Free text name for lithology category of sample, e.g. biotite-hornblende granite, lithofeldspathic sandstone, calcareous arkose, biotite schist.

StableIsotopes.name: SampledGeologicUnit
StableIsotopes.description: Name of geologic unit that was sampled. Include hierarchy of names if the unit is part of a higher-rank geologic unit, e.g. Group name/Formation name, or Formation/Member, or Group/ Formation. Spell out unit names in full.

StableIsotopes.name: SampledGeologicUnitAge
StableIsotopes.description: Age of a sample as described by the stratigraphic  era, period, etc. “Cretaceous”; “Upper Miocene”.

StableIsotopes.name: County
StableIsotopes.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

StableIsotopes.name: State
StableIsotopes.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

StableIsotopes.name: LatDegree
StableIsotopes.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

StableIsotopes.name: LongDegree
StableIsotopes.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

StableIsotopes.name: SRS
StableIsotopes.description: The spatial reference system. It is recommended that an EPSG code be used to identify the SRS used to specify the location.  If an EPSG code is used, identify it as such with the prefix 'EPSG:' For common EPSG codes, see the Data Valid Terms tab. EPSG:4326 is the identifier for WGS84, and should be the text in this field. EPSG stands for European Petroleum Survey Group. EPSSG codes can be dereferenced by putting the code in this URL (replace 4326) http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/4326/.

StableIsotopes.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
StableIsotopes.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

StableIsotopes.name: LocalityTerms
StableIsotopes.description: Additional information or more geographic names associated with sample collection location; if multiple names supplied, delimit with pipe '|' character, e.g. Arizona | La Paz County | Harquahala Mountains | Browns Canyon.

StableIsotopes.name: DatumElevation
StableIsotopes.description: The point of reference against which elevation measurements are made. Best practice: use mean sea level (MSL) as datum.

StableIsotopes.name: Elevation
StableIsotopes.description: Elevation at ground level the sample came from. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL).

StableIsotopes.name: ElevationUnits
StableIsotopes.description: Units used to report all elevation and depth information.

StableIsotopes.name: Citation
StableIsotopes.description: Free text citation, using some standard journal format, that identifies a publication in which this sample was defined.  For samples that are not described in publications, text description of where sample came from should include name of person or organization to contact to access sample.

StableIsotopes.name: Source
StableIsotopes.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining feature; may be author-date type citation, but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe ('|') character.

StableIsotopes.name: MetadataURI
StableIsotopes.description: URI identifying (and ideally dereferencing to get) a full formal metadata record for the observation report. A time series of observations may all reference the same metadata record that provides contact information and details on procedure, etc.

StableIsotopes.name: RelatedResource
StableIsotopes.description: This may be one to many http links to resources (logs, pictures or other documents if available online. Should be an http:// address (URL)) related to the observation described in each record. Delimit multiple values with the pipe '|' character.

StableIsotopes.name: AnalysisType
StableIsotopes.description: Type of analysis used to obtain the results in this record.

StableIsotopes.name: AnalysisDate
StableIsotopes.description: Date for the record (date on which measurement or test was made. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

StableIsotopes.name: Laboratory
StableIsotopes.description: If a Laboratory performed the analysis, include name and address here.

StableIsotopes.name: ProcedureSummary
StableIsotopes.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

StableIsotopes.name: UpdateTimeStamp
StableIsotopes.description: Date of last time line of data was updated or corrected by the service provider.(Format: 2012-06-22T00:00).

RareEarths.name: OBJECTID
RareEarths.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

RareEarths.name: AnalysisURI
RareEarths.description: A unique identifier for a discrete analysis of a specimen taken from a feature. The feature from which the specimen was taken will be identified by its own URI.

RareEarths.name: AnalysisName
RareEarths.description: The human-intelligible name of the analysis. May be a concatenation of analysis type, feature name, and specimen label. This element is specific, not generic; i.e., do not use generic terms such as "Analyte Analysis".

RareEarths.name: OtherAnalysisID
RareEarths.description: Alternative identifier(s) for this analysis. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe '|' character. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the prefix would be azgs: and the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

RareEarths.name: Notes
RareEarths.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about methods, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

RareEarths.name: DetectionLimitURI
RareEarths.description: Unique identifier that specifies the Limits of the test. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature. Unique identifier for each set of samples, each analyzed using the same method, technique and using the same equipment.

RareEarths.name: SamplingFeatureName
RareEarths.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

RareEarths.name: SamplingFeatureURI
RareEarths.description: Unique Identifier for the particular site (station) or well where the sample(s) came from. For wells, this might be the HeaderURI or API number used in other metadata files. If unavailable, state 'missing'. SamplingFeature is a concept that represents the feature that accesses the part of the Earth from which the sample came, e.g. outcrop, borehole, dredge haul.

RareEarths.name: SpecimenID
RareEarths.description: ID given to the specimen by the collector(s). Recommended practice: include a short abbreviation in a prefix indicating the authority or scope of the identifier (e.g. 'usgs:'); any prefixes should be explained in the dataset metadata.

Volatiles.description: If a Laboratory performed the analysis, include name and address here.

Volatiles.name: ProcedureSummary
Volatiles.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

Volatiles.name: UpdateTimeStamp
Volatiles.description: Date of last time line of data was updated or corrected by the service provider.(Format: 2012-06-22T00:00).

NobleGases.name: OBJECTID
NobleGases.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

NobleGases.name: AnalysisURI
NobleGases.description: A unique identifier for a discrete analysis of a specimen taken from a feature. The feature from which the specimen was taken will be identified by its own URI.

NobleGases.name: AnalysisName
NobleGases.description: The human-intelligible name of the analysis. May be a concatenation of analysis type, feature name, and specimen label. This element is specific, not generic; i.e., do not use generic terms such as "Analyte Analysis".

NobleGases.name: OtherAnalysisID
NobleGases.description: Alternative identifier(s) for this analysis. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe '|' character. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the prefix would be azgs: and the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

NobleGases.name: Notes
NobleGases.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about methods, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

NobleGases.name: DetectionLimitURI
NobleGases.description: Unique identifier that specifies the Limits of the test. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature. Unique identifier for each set of samples, each analyzed using the same method, technique and using the same equipment.

NobleGases.name: SamplingFeatureName
NobleGases.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

NobleGases.name: SamplingFeatureURI
NobleGases.description: Unique Identifier for the particular site (station) or well where the sample(s) came from. For wells, this might be the HeaderURI or API number used in other metadata files. If unavailable, state 'missing'. SamplingFeature is a concept that represents the feature that accesses the part of the Earth from which the sample came, e.g. outcrop, borehole, dredge haul.

NobleGases.name: SpecimenID
NobleGases.description: ID given to the specimen by the collector(s). Recommended practice: include a short abbreviation in a prefix indicating the authority or scope of the identifier (e.g. 'usgs:'); any prefixes should be explained in the dataset metadata.

NobleGases.name: OtherSpecimenID
NobleGases.description: Alternative identifier(s) for the feature. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

NobleGases.name: SpecimenURI
NobleGases.description: Unique identifier for sample; should include protocol prefix with known meaning, delimited by a ':' (colon), e.g. igsn:24623570 or http://resources.usgin.org/uri-gin/AZGS/sample/24623570.

NobleGases.name: ParentSampleURI
NobleGases.description: Identifier for a sample from which this specimen was sub-sampled. E.g. if a piece from a registered core is registered as a separate sample, this would be the identifier for the core.

NobleGases.name: Label
NobleGases.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as feature name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

NobleGases.name: SpecimenCollectionDate
NobleGases.description: Date on which specimen sample was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

NobleGases.name: SpecimenLabel
NobleGases.description: Short text string to identify/characterize the sample used in this observation; may include one or more sample names as provided by the sample collector or analyzing laboratory.

NobleGases.name: SpecimenDescription
NobleGases.description: Free text field for any additional observations or other information regarding the feature (size, weight, quality, lithology, locality, etc).

NobleGases.name: SampleCollectionMethod
NobleGases.description: Method used to collect specimen; may be hand sample, core or drill cuttings.

NobleGases.name: SpecimenType
NobleGases.description: Term to describe the type of specimen. Use term from list of Specimen types. If the specimen type collected is not present on this list, add the specimen type to the list in the example column.

NobleGases.name: SpecimenCollector
NobleGases.description: Free text specification of person, organization, affiliation, address, etc. for party that originally collected specimen. Include contact information if available.

NobleGases.name: MaterialClass
NobleGases.description: Category from simple material classification scheme e.g. rock, sediment, aqueous liquid, other liquid, gas, biological material.

NobleGases.name: LithologyTerms
NobleGases.description: Description of the lithology of surface geology or geologic column for well interval, e.g. arkose, granite, limestone, sandstone, schist. Recommend using CGI simple lithology vocabulary (see tab in this workbook). Use to account for EarthChem Material, EarthChem Type, EarthChem Composition, alluvium, 36-40': gravels; etc.

NobleGases.name: RockName
NobleGases.description: Free text name for lithology category of sample, e.g. biotite-hornblende granite, lithofeldspathic sandstone, calcareous arkose, biotite schist.

NobleGases.name: SampledGeologicUnit
NobleGases.description: Name of geologic unit that was sampled. Include hierarchy of names if the unit is part of a higher-rank geologic unit, e.g. Group name/Formation name, or Formation/Member, or Group/ Formation. Spell out unit names in full.

NobleGases.name: SampledGeologicUnitAge
NobleGases.description: Age of a sample as described by the stratigraphic  era, period, etc. “Cretaceous”; “Upper Miocene”.

NobleGases.name: County
NobleGases.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

NobleGases.name: State
NobleGases.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

NobleGases.name: LatDegree
NobleGases.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

NobleGases.name: LongDegree
NobleGases.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

NobleGases.name: SRS
NobleGases.description: The spatial reference system. It is recommended that an EPSG code be used to identify the SRS used to specify the location.  If an EPSG code is used, identify it as such with the prefix 'EPSG:' For common EPSG codes, see the Data Valid Terms tab. EPSG:4326 is the identifier for WGS84, and should be the text in this field. EPSG stands for European Petroleum Survey Group. EPSSG codes can be dereferenced by putting the code in this URL (replace 4326) http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/4326/.

NobleGases.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
NobleGases.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

NobleGases.name: LocalityTerms
NobleGases.description: Additional information or more geographic names associated with sample collection location; if multiple names supplied, delimit with pipe '|' character, e.g. Arizona | La Paz County | Harquahala Mountains | Browns Canyon.

NobleGases.name: DatumElevation
NobleGases.description: The point of reference against which elevation measurements are made. Best practice: use mean sea level (MSL) as datum.

NobleGases.name: Elevation
NobleGases.description: Elevation at ground level the sample came from. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL).

NobleGases.name: ElevationUnits
NobleGases.description: Units used to report all elevation and depth information.

NobleGases.name: Citation
NobleGases.description: Free text citation, using some standard journal format, that identifies a publication in which this sample was defined.  For samples that are not described in publications, text description of where sample came from should include name of person or organization to contact to access sample.

NobleGases.name: Source
NobleGases.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining feature; may be author-date type citation, but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe ('|') character.

NobleGases.name: MetadataURI
NobleGases.description: URI identifying (and ideally dereferencing to get) a full formal metadata record for the observation report. A time series of observations may all reference the same metadata record that provides contact information and details on procedure, etc.

NobleGases.name: RelatedResource
NobleGases.description: This may be one to many http links to resources (logs, pictures or other documents if available online. Should be an http:// address (URL)) related to the observation described in each record. Delimit multiple values with the pipe '|' character.

NobleGases.name: AnalysisType
NobleGases.description: Type of analysis used to obtain the results in this record.

NobleGases.name: AnalysisDate
NobleGases.description: Date for the record (date on which measurement or test was made. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

NobleGases.name: Laboratory
NobleGases.description: If a Laboratory performed the analysis, include name and address here.

NobleGases.name: ProcedureSummary
NobleGases.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

NobleGases.name: UpdateTimeStamp
NobleGases.description: Date of last time line of data was updated or corrected by the service provider.(Format: 2012-06-22T00:00).

USeries.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

USeries.name: SRS
USeries.description: The spatial reference system. It is recommended that an EPSG code be used to identify the SRS used to specify the location.  If an EPSG code is used, identify it as such with the prefix 'EPSG:' For common EPSG codes, see the Data Valid Terms tab. EPSG:4326 is the identifier for WGS84, and should be the text in this field. EPSG stands for European Petroleum Survey Group. EPSSG codes can be dereferenced by putting the code in this URL (replace 4326) http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/4326/.

USeries.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
USeries.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

USeries.name: LocalityTerms
USeries.description: Additional information or more geographic names associated with sample collection location; if multiple names supplied, delimit with pipe '|' character, e.g. Arizona | La Paz County | Harquahala Mountains | Browns Canyon.

USeries.name: DatumElevation
USeries.description: The point of reference against which elevation measurements are made. Best practice: use mean sea level (MSL) as datum.

USeries.name: Elevation
USeries.description: Elevation at ground level the sample came from. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL).

USeries.name: ElevationUnits
USeries.description: Units used to report all elevation and depth information.

USeries.name: Citation
USeries.description: Free text citation, using some standard journal format, that identifies a publication in which this sample was defined.  For samples that are not described in publications, text description of where sample came from should include name of person or organization to contact to access sample.

USeries.name: Source
USeries.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining feature; may be author-date type citation, but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe ('|') character.

USeries.name: MetadataURI
USeries.description: URI identifying (and ideally dereferencing to get) a full formal metadata record for the observation report. A time series of observations may all reference the same metadata record that provides contact information and details on procedure, etc.

USeries.name: RelatedResource
USeries.description: This may be one to many http links to resources (logs, pictures or other documents if available online. Should be an http:// address (URL)) related to the observation described in each record. Delimit multiple values with the pipe '|' character.

USeries.name: AnalysisType
USeries.description: Type of analysis used to obtain the results in this record.

USeries.name: AnalysisDate
USeries.description: Date for the record (date on which measurement or test was made. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

USeries.name: Laboratory
USeries.description: If a Laboratory performed the analysis, include name and address here.

USeries.name: ProcedureSummary
USeries.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

USeries.name: UpdateTimeStamp
USeries.description: Date of last time line of data was updated or corrected by the service provider.(Format: 2012-06-22T00:00).

Isotopes.name: OBJECTID
Isotopes.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

Isotopes.name: AnalysisURI
Isotopes.description: A unique identifier for a discrete analysis of a specimen taken from a feature. The feature from which the specimen was taken will be identified by its own URI.

Isotopes.name: AnalysisName
Isotopes.description: The human-intelligible name of the analysis. May be a concatenation of analysis type, feature name, and specimen label. This element is specific, not generic; i.e., do not use generic terms such as "Analyte Analysis".

Isotopes.name: OtherAnalysisID
Isotopes.description: Alternative identifier(s) for this analysis. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe '|' character. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the prefix would be azgs: and the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

Isotopes.name: Notes
Isotopes.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about methods, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

Isotopes.name: DetectionLimitURI
Isotopes.description: Unique identifier that specifies the Limits of the test. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature. Unique identifier for each set of samples, each analyzed using the same method, technique and using the same equipment.

Isotopes.name: SamplingFeatureName
Isotopes.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

Isotopes.name: SamplingFeatureURI
Isotopes.description: Unique Identifier for the particular site (station) or well where the sample(s) came from. For wells, this might be the HeaderURI or API number used in other metadata files. If unavailable, state 'missing'. SamplingFeature is a concept that represents the feature that accesses the part of the Earth from which the sample came, e.g. outcrop, borehole, dredge haul.

Isotopes.name: SpecimenID
Isotopes.description: ID given to the specimen by the collector(s). Recommended practice: include a short abbreviation in a prefix indicating the authority or scope of the identifier (e.g. 'usgs:'); any prefixes should be explained in the dataset metadata.

Isotopes.name: OtherSpecimenID
Isotopes.description: Alternative identifier(s) for the feature. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

Isotopes.name: SpecimenURI
Isotopes.description: Unique identifier for sample; should include protocol prefix with known meaning, delimited by a ':' (colon), e.g. igsn:24623570 or http://resources.usgin.org/uri-gin/AZGS/sample/24623570.

Isotopes.name: ParentSampleURI
Isotopes.description: Identifier for a sample from which this specimen was sub-sampled. E.g. if a piece from a registered core is registered as a separate sample, this would be the identifier for the core.

Isotopes.name: Label
Isotopes.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as feature name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

Isotopes.name: SpecimenCollectionDate
Isotopes.description: Date on which specimen sample was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

Isotopes.name: SpecimenLabel
Isotopes.description: Short text string to identify/characterize the sample used in this observation; may include one or more sample names as provided by the sample collector or analyzing laboratory.

Isotopes.name: SpecimenDescription
Isotopes.description: Free text field for any additional observations or other information regarding the feature (size, weight, quality, lithology, locality, etc).

Isotopes.name: SampleCollectionMethod
Isotopes.description: Method used to collect specimen; may be hand sample, core or drill cuttings.

Isotopes.name: SpecimenType
Isotopes.description: Term to describe the type of specimen. Use term from list of Specimen types. If the specimen type collected is not present on this list, add the specimen type to the list in the example column.

Isotopes.name: SpecimenCollector
Isotopes.description: Free text specification of person, organization, affiliation, address, etc. for party that originally collected specimen. Include contact information if available.

Isotopes.name: MaterialClass
Isotopes.description: Category from simple material classification scheme e.g. rock, sediment, aqueous liquid, other liquid, gas, biological material.

Isotopes.name: LithologyTerms
Isotopes.description: Description of the lithology of surface geology or geologic column for well interval, e.g. arkose, granite, limestone, sandstone, schist. Recommend using CGI simple lithology vocabulary (see tab in this workbook). Use to account for EarthChem Material, EarthChem Type, EarthChem Composition, alluvium, 36-40': gravels; etc.

Isotopes.name: RockName
Isotopes.description: Free text name for lithology category of sample, e.g. biotite-hornblende granite, lithofeldspathic sandstone, calcareous arkose, biotite schist.

Isotopes.name: SampledGeologicUnit
Isotopes.description: Name of geologic unit that was sampled. Include hierarchy of names if the unit is part of a higher-rank geologic unit, e.g. Group name/Formation name, or Formation/Member, or Group/ Formation. Spell out unit names in full.

Isotopes.name: SampledGeologicUnitAge
Isotopes.description: Age of a sample as described by the stratigraphic  era, period, etc. “Cretaceous”; “Upper Miocene”.

Isotopes.name: County
Isotopes.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

Isotopes.name: State
Isotopes.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

Isotopes.name: LatDegree
Isotopes.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

Isotopes.name: LongDegree
Isotopes.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

Isotopes.description: Additional information or more geographic names associated with sample collection location; if multiple names supplied, delimit with pipe '|' character, e.g. Arizona | La Paz County | Harquahala Mountains | Browns Canyon.

Isotopes.name: DatumElevation

Isotopes.name: Elevation
Isotopes.description: Elevation at ground level the sample came from. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL).

Isotopes.name: ElevationUnits
Isotopes.description: Units used to report all elevation and depth information.

WRMajorElements.description: Short text string to identify/characterize the sample used in this observation; may include one or more sample names as provided by the sample collector or analyzing laboratory.

WRMajorElements.name: SpecimenDescription
WRMajorElements.description: Free text field for any additional observations or other information regarding the feature (size, weight, quality, lithology, locality, etc).

WRMajorElements.name: SampleCollectionMethod
WRMajorElements.description: Method used to collect specimen; may be hand sample, core or drill cuttings.

WRMajorElements.name: SpecimenType
WRMajorElements.description: Term to describe the type of specimen. Use term from list of Specimen types. If the specimen type collected is not present on this list, add the specimen type to the list in the example column.

WRMajorElements.name: SpecimenCollector
WRMajorElements.description: Free text specification of person, organization, affiliation, address, etc. for party that originally collected specimen. Include contact information if available.

WRMajorElements.name: MaterialClass
WRMajorElements.description: Category from simple material classification scheme e.g. rock, sediment, aqueous liquid, other liquid, gas, biological material.

WRMajorElements.name: LithologyTerms
WRMajorElements.description: Description of the lithology of surface geology or geologic column for well interval, e.g. arkose, granite, limestone, sandstone, schist. Recommend using CGI simple lithology vocabulary (see tab in this workbook). Use to account for EarthChem Material, EarthChem Type, EarthChem Composition, alluvium, 36-40': gravels; etc.

WRMajorElements.name: RockName
WRMajorElements.description: Free text name for lithology category of sample, e.g. biotite-hornblende granite, lithofeldspathic sandstone, calcareous arkose, biotite schist.

WRMajorElements.name: SampledGeologicUnit
WRMajorElements.description: Name of geologic unit that was sampled. Include hierarchy of names if the unit is part of a higher-rank geologic unit, e.g. Group name/Formation name, or Formation/Member, or Group/ Formation. Spell out unit names in full.

WRMajorElements.name: SampledGeologicUnitAge
WRMajorElements.description: Age of a sample as described by the stratigraphic  era, period, etc. “Cretaceous”; “Upper Miocene”.

WRMajorElements.name: County
WRMajorElements.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

WRMajorElements.name: State
WRMajorElements.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

WRMajorElements.name: LatDegree
WRMajorElements.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

WRMajorElements.name: LongDegree
WRMajorElements.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

WRMajorElements.name: SRS
WRMajorElements.description: The spatial reference system. It is recommended that an EPSG code be used to identify the SRS used to specify the location.  If an EPSG code is used, identify it as such with the prefix 'EPSG:' For common EPSG codes, see the Data Valid Terms tab. EPSG:4326 is the identifier for WGS84, and should be the text in this field. EPSG stands for European Petroleum Survey Group. EPSSG codes can be dereferenced by putting the code in this URL (replace 4326) http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/4326/.

WRMajorElements.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
WRMajorElements.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

WRMajorElements.name: LocalityTerms
WRMajorElements.description: Additional information or more geographic names associated with sample collection location; if multiple names supplied, delimit with pipe '|' character, e.g. Arizona | La Paz County | Harquahala Mountains | Browns Canyon.

WRMajorElements.name: DatumElevation
WRMajorElements.description: The point of reference against which elevation measurements are made. Best practice: use mean sea level (MSL) as datum.

WRMajorElements.name: Elevation
WRMajorElements.description: Elevation at ground level the sample came from. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL).

WRMajorElements.name: ElevationUnits
WRMajorElements.description: Units used to report all elevation and depth information.

WRMajorElements.name: Citation
WRMajorElements.description: Free text citation, using some standard journal format, that identifies a publication in which this sample was defined.  For samples that are not described in publications, text description of where sample came from should include name of person or organization to contact to access sample.

WRMajorElements.name: Source
WRMajorElements.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining feature; may be author-date type citation, but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe ('|') character.

WRMajorElements.name: MetadataURI
WRMajorElements.description: URI identifying (and ideally dereferencing to get) a full formal metadata record for the observation report. A time series of observations may all reference the same metadata record that provides contact information and details on procedure, etc.

WRMajorElements.name: RelatedResource
WRMajorElements.description: This may be one to many http links to resources (logs, pictures or other documents if available online. Should be an http:// address (URL)) related to the observation described in each record. Delimit multiple values with the pipe '|' character.

WRMajorElements.name: AnalysisType
WRMajorElements.description: Type of analysis used to obtain the results in this record.

WRMajorElements.name: AnalysisDate
WRMajorElements.description: Date for the record (date on which measurement or test was made. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

WRMajorElements.name: Laboratory
WRMajorElements.description: If a Laboratory performed the analysis, include name and address here.

WRMajorElements.name: ProcedureSummary
WRMajorElements.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

WRMajorElements.name: UpdateTimeStamp
WRMajorElements.description: Date of last time line of data was updated or corrected by the service provider.(Format: 2012-06-22T00:00).

StableIsotopes.name: OBJECTID
StableIsotopes.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

StableIsotopes.name: AnalysisURI
StableIsotopes.description: A unique identifier for a discrete analysis of a specimen taken from a feature. The feature from which the specimen was taken will be identified by its own URI.

StableIsotopes.name: AnalysisName
StableIsotopes.description: The human-intelligible name of the analysis. May be a concatenation of analysis type, feature name, and specimen label. This element is specific, not generic; i.e., do not use generic terms such as "Analyte Analysis".

StableIsotopes.name: OtherAnalysisID
StableIsotopes.description: Alternative identifier(s) for this analysis. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe '|' character. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the prefix would be azgs: and the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

StableIsotopes.name: Notes
StableIsotopes.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about methods, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

StableIsotopes.name: DetectionLimitURI
StableIsotopes.description: Unique identifier that specifies the Limits of the test. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature. Unique identifier for each set of samples, each analyzed using the same method, technique and using the same equipment.

StableIsotopes.name: SamplingFeatureName
StableIsotopes.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

StableIsotopes.name: SamplingFeatureURI
StableIsotopes.description: Unique Identifier for the particular site (station) or well where the sample(s) came from. For wells, this might be the HeaderURI or API number used in other metadata files. If unavailable, state 'missing'. SamplingFeature is a concept that represents the feature that accesses the part of the Earth from which the sample came, e.g. outcrop, borehole, dredge haul.

StableIsotopes.name: SpecimenID
StableIsotopes.description: ID given to the specimen by the collector(s). Recommended practice: include a short abbreviation in a prefix indicating the authority or scope of the identifier (e.g. 'usgs:'); any prefixes should be explained in the dataset metadata.

StableIsotopes.name: OtherSpecimenID
StableIsotopes.description: Alternative identifier(s) for the feature. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

StableIsotopes.name: SpecimenURI
StableIsotopes.description: Unique identifier for sample; should include protocol prefix with known meaning, delimited by a ':' (colon), e.g. igsn:24623570 or http://resources.usgin.org/uri-gin/AZGS/sample/24623570.

StableIsotopes.name: ParentSampleURI
StableIsotopes.description: Identifier for a sample from which this specimen was sub-sampled. E.g. if a piece from a registered core is registered as a separate sample, this would be the identifier for the core.

StableIsotopes.name: Label
StableIsotopes.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as feature name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

StableIsotopes.name: SpecimenCollectionDate
StableIsotopes.description: Date on which specimen sample was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

Volatiles.name: OBJECTID
Volatiles.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

Volatiles.name: AnalysisURI
Volatiles.description: A unique identifier for a discrete analysis of a specimen taken from a feature. The feature from which the specimen was taken will be identified by its own URI.

Volatiles.name: AnalysisName
Volatiles.description: The human-intelligible name of the analysis. May be a concatenation of analysis type, feature name, and specimen label. This element is specific, not generic; i.e., do not use generic terms such as "Analyte Analysis".

Volatiles.name: OtherAnalysisID
Volatiles.description: Alternative identifier(s) for this analysis. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe '|' character. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the prefix would be azgs: and the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

Volatiles.name: Notes
Volatiles.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about methods, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

Volatiles.name: DetectionLimitURI
Volatiles.description: Unique identifier that specifies the Limits of the test. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature. Unique identifier for each set of samples, each analyzed using the same method, technique and using the same equipment.

Volatiles.name: SamplingFeatureName
Volatiles.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

Volatiles.name: SamplingFeatureURI
Volatiles.description: Unique Identifier for the particular site (station) or well where the sample(s) came from. For wells, this might be the HeaderURI or API number used in other metadata files. If unavailable, state 'missing'. SamplingFeature is a concept that represents the feature that accesses the part of the Earth from which the sample came, e.g. outcrop, borehole, dredge haul.

Volatiles.name: SpecimenID
Volatiles.description: ID given to the specimen by the collector(s). Recommended practice: include a short abbreviation in a prefix indicating the authority or scope of the identifier (e.g. 'usgs:'); any prefixes should be explained in the dataset metadata.

Volatiles.name: OtherSpecimenID
Volatiles.description: Alternative identifier(s) for the feature. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

Volatiles.name: SpecimenURI
Volatiles.description: Unique identifier for sample; should include protocol prefix with known meaning, delimited by a ':' (colon), e.g. igsn:24623570 or http://resources.usgin.org/uri-gin/AZGS/sample/24623570.

Volatiles.name: ParentSampleURI
Volatiles.description: Identifier for a sample from which this specimen was sub-sampled. E.g. if a piece from a registered core is registered as a separate sample, this would be the identifier for the core.

Volatiles.name: Label
Volatiles.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as feature name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

Volatiles.name: SpecimenCollectionDate
Volatiles.description: Date on which specimen sample was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

Volatiles.name: SpecimenLabel
Volatiles.description: Short text string to identify/characterize the sample used in this observation; may include one or more sample names as provided by the sample collector or analyzing laboratory.

Volatiles.name: SpecimenDescription
Volatiles.description: Free text field for any additional observations or other information regarding the feature (size, weight, quality, lithology, locality, etc).

Volatiles.name: SampleCollectionMethod
Volatiles.description: Method used to collect specimen; may be hand sample, core or drill cuttings.

Volatiles.name: SpecimenType
Volatiles.description: Term to describe the type of specimen. Use term from list of Specimen types. If the specimen type collected is not present on this list, add the specimen type to the list in the example column.

Volatiles.name: SpecimenCollector
Volatiles.description: Free text specification of person, organization, affiliation, address, etc. for party that originally collected specimen. Include contact information if available.

Volatiles.name: MaterialClass
Volatiles.description: Category from simple material classification scheme e.g. rock, sediment, aqueous liquid, other liquid, gas, biological material.

Volatiles.name: LithologyTerms
Volatiles.description: Description of the lithology of surface geology or geologic column for well interval, e.g. arkose, granite, limestone, sandstone, schist. Recommend using CGI simple lithology vocabulary (see tab in this workbook). Use to account for EarthChem Material, EarthChem Type, EarthChem Composition, alluvium, 36-40': gravels; etc.

Volatiles.name: RockName
Volatiles.description: Free text name for lithology category of sample, e.g. biotite-hornblende granite, lithofeldspathic sandstone, calcareous arkose, biotite schist.

Volatiles.name: SampledGeologicUnit
Volatiles.description: Name of geologic unit that was sampled. Include hierarchy of names if the unit is part of a higher-rank geologic unit, e.g. Group name/Formation name, or Formation/Member, or Group/ Formation. Spell out unit names in full.

Volatiles.name: SampledGeologicUnitAge
Volatiles.description: Age of a sample as described by the stratigraphic  era, period, etc. “Cretaceous”; “Upper Miocene”.

Volatiles.name: County
Volatiles.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

Volatiles.name: State
Volatiles.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

Volatiles.name: LatDegree
Volatiles.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

Volatiles.name: LongDegree
Volatiles.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

Volatiles.name: SRS
Volatiles.description: The spatial reference system. It is recommended that an EPSG code be used to identify the SRS used to specify the location.  If an EPSG code is used, identify it as such with the prefix 'EPSG:' For common EPSG codes, see the Data Valid Terms tab. EPSG:4326 is the identifier for WGS84, and should be the text in this field. EPSG stands for European Petroleum Survey Group. EPSSG codes can be dereferenced by putting the code in this URL (replace 4326) http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/4326/.

Volatiles.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
Volatiles.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

Volatiles.name: LocalityTerms
Volatiles.description: Additional information or more geographic names associated with sample collection location; if multiple names supplied, delimit with pipe '|' character, e.g. Arizona | La Paz County | Harquahala Mountains | Browns Canyon.

Volatiles.name: DatumElevation
Volatiles.description: The point of reference against which elevation measurements are made. Best practice: use mean sea level (MSL) as datum.

Volatiles.name: Elevation
Volatiles.description: Elevation at ground level the sample came from. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL).

Volatiles.name: ElevationUnits
Volatiles.description: Units used to report all elevation and depth information.

Volatiles.name: Citation
Volatiles.description: Free text citation, using some standard journal format, that identifies a publication in which this sample was defined.  For samples that are not described in publications, text description of where sample came from should include name of person or organization to contact to access sample.

Volatiles.name: Source
Volatiles.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining feature; may be author-date type citation, but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe ('|') character.

Volatiles.name: MetadataURI
Volatiles.description: URI identifying (and ideally dereferencing to get) a full formal metadata record for the observation report. A time series of observations may all reference the same metadata record that provides contact information and details on procedure, etc.

Volatiles.name: RelatedResource
Volatiles.description: This may be one to many http links to resources (logs, pictures or other documents if available online. Should be an http:// address (URL)) related to the observation described in each record. Delimit multiple values with the pipe '|' character.

Volatiles.name: AnalysisType
Volatiles.description: Type of analysis used to obtain the results in this record.

Volatiles.name: AnalysisDate
Volatiles.description: Date for the record (date on which measurement or test was made. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

Volatiles.name: Laboratory
Volatiles.description: If a Laboratory performed the analysis, include name and address here.

Volatiles.name: ProcedureSummary
Volatiles.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

Volatiles.name: UpdateTimeStamp
Volatiles.description: Date of last time line of data was updated or corrected by the service provider.(Format: 2012-06-22T00:00).
