EPSG stands for European Petroleum Survey Group. EPSSG codes can be dereferenced by putting the code in this URL (replace 4326) http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/4326/.

SingleAnalytes.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
SingleAnalytes.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

SingleAnalytes.name: LocalityTerms
SingleAnalytes.description: Additional information or more geographic names associated with sample collection location; if multiple names supplied, delimit with pipe '|' character, e.g. Arizona | La Paz County | Harquahala Mountains | Browns Canyon.

SingleAnalytes.name: DatumElevation
SingleAnalytes.description: The point of reference against which elevation measurements are made. Best practice: use mean sea level (MSL) as datum.

SingleAnalytes.name: Elevation
SingleAnalytes.description: Elevation at ground level the sample came from. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL).

SingleAnalytes.name: ElevationUnits
SingleAnalytes.description: Units used to report all elevation and depth information.

SingleAnalytes.name: Citation
SingleAnalytes.description: Free text citation, using some standard journal format, that identifies a publication in which this sample was defined.  For samples that are not described in publications, text description of where sample came from should include name of person or organization to contact to access sample.

SingleAnalytes.name: Source
SingleAnalytes.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining feature; may be author-date type citation, but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe ('|') character.

SingleAnalytes.name: MetadataURI
SingleAnalytes.description: URI identifying (and ideally dereferencing to get) a full formal metadata record for the observation report. A time series of observations may all reference the same metadata record that provides contact information and details on procedure, etc.

SingleAnalytes.name: RelatedResource
SingleAnalytes.description: This may be one to many http links to resources (logs, pictures or other documents if available online. Should be an http:// address (URL)) related to the observation described in each record. Delimit multiple values with the pipe '|' character.

SingleAnalytes.name: AnalysisType
SingleAnalytes.description: Type of analysis used to obtain the results in this record.

SingleAnalytes.name: AnalysisDate
SingleAnalytes.description: Date for the record (date on which measurement or test was made. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

SingleAnalytes.name: Laboratory
SingleAnalytes.description: If a Laboratory performed the analysis, include name and address here.

SingleAnalytes.name: ProcedureSummary
SingleAnalytes.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

SingleAnalytes.name: UpdateTimeStamp
SingleAnalytes.description: Date of last time line of data was updated or corrected by the service provider.(Format: 2012-06-22T00:00).

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: OBJECTID
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: AnalysisURI
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: A unique identifier for a discrete analysis of a specimen taken from a feature. The feature from which the specimen was taken will be identified by its own URI.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: AnalysisName
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: The human-intelligible name of the analysis. May be a concatenation of analysis type, feature name, and specimen label. This element is specific, not generic; i.e., do not use generic terms such as "Analyte Analysis".

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: OtherAnalysisID
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Alternative identifier(s) for this analysis. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe '|' character. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the prefix would be azgs: and the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: Notes
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about methods, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: DetectionLimitURI
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Unique identifier that specifies the Limits of the test. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature. Unique identifier for each set of samples, each analyzed using the same method, technique and using the same equipment.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: SamplingFeatureName
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: SamplingFeatureURI
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Unique Identifier for the particular site (station) or well where the sample(s) came from. For wells, this might be the HeaderURI or API number used in other metadata files. If unavailable, state 'missing'. SamplingFeature is a concept that represents the feature that accesses the part of the Earth from which the sample came, e.g. outcrop, borehole, dredge haul.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: SpecimenID
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: ID given to the specimen by the collector(s). Recommended practice: include a short abbreviation in a prefix indicating the authority or scope of the identifier (e.g. 'usgs:'); any prefixes should be explained in the dataset metadata.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: OtherSpecimenID
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Alternative identifier(s) for the feature. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: SpecimenURI
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Unique identifier for sample; should include protocol prefix with known meaning, delimited by a ':' (colon), e.g. igsn:24623570 or http://resources.usgin.org/uri-gin/AZGS/sample/24623570.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: ParentSampleURI
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Identifier for a sample from which this specimen was sub-sampled. E.g. if a piece from a registered core is registered as a separate sample, this would be the identifier for the core.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: Label
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as feature name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: SpecimenCollectionDate
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Date on which specimen sample was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: SpecimenLabel
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Short text string to identify/characterize the sample used in this observation; may include one or more sample names as provided by the sample collector or analyzing laboratory.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: SpecimenDescription
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Free text field for any additional observations or other information regarding the feature (size, weight, quality, lithology, locality, etc).

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: SampleCollectionMethod
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Method used to collect specimen; may be hand sample, core or drill cuttings.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: SpecimenType
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Term to describe the type of specimen. Use term from list of Specimen types. If the specimen type collected is not present on this list, add the specimen type to the list in the example column.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: SpecimenCollector
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Free text specification of person, organization, affiliation, address, etc. for party that originally collected specimen. Include contact information if available.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: MaterialClass
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Category from simple material classification scheme e.g. rock, sediment, aqueous liquid, other liquid, gas, biological material.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: LithologyTerms
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Description of the lithology of surface geology or geologic column for well interval, e.g. arkose, granite, limestone, sandstone, schist. Recommend using CGI simple lithology vocabulary (see tab in this workbook). Use to account for EarthChem Material, EarthChem Type, EarthChem Composition, alluvium, 36-40': gravels; etc.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: RockName
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Free text name for lithology category of sample, e.g. biotite-hornblende granite, lithofeldspathic sandstone, calcareous arkose, biotite schist.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: SampledGeologicUnit
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Name of geologic unit that was sampled. Include hierarchy of names if the unit is part of a higher-rank geologic unit, e.g. Group name/Formation name, or Formation/Member, or Group/ Formation. Spell out unit names in full.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: SampledGeologicUnitAge
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Age of a sample as described by the stratigraphic  era, period, etc. “Cretaceous”; “Upper Miocene”.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: County
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: State
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: LatDegree
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: LongDegree
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature; values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: SRS
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: The spatial reference system. It is recommended that an EPSG code be used to identify the SRS used to specify the location.  If an EPSG code is used, identify it as such with the prefix 'EPSG:' For common EPSG codes, see the Data Valid Terms tab. EPSG:4326 is the identifier for WGS84, and should be the text in this field. EPSG stands for European Petroleum Survey Group. EPSSG codes can be dereferenced by putting the code in this URL (replace 4326) http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/4326/.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: LocalityTerms
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Additional information or more geographic names associated with sample collection location; if multiple names supplied, delimit with pipe '|' character, e.g. Arizona | La Paz County | Harquahala Mountains | Browns Canyon.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: DatumElevation
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: The point of reference against which elevation measurements are made. Best practice: use mean sea level (MSL) as datum.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: Elevation
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Elevation at ground level the sample came from. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL).

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: ElevationUnits
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Units used to report all elevation and depth information.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: Citation
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Free text citation, using some standard journal format, that identifies a publication in which this sample was defined.  For samples that are not described in publications, text description of where sample came from should include name of person or organization to contact to access sample.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: Source
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining feature; may be author-date type citation, but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe ('|') character.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: MetadataURI
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: URI identifying (and ideally dereferencing to get) a full formal metadata record for the observation report. A time series of observations may all reference the same metadata record that provides contact information and details on procedure, etc.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: RelatedResource
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: This may be one to many http links to resources (logs, pictures or other documents if available online. Should be an http:// address (URL)) related to the observation described in each record. Delimit multiple values with the pipe '|' character.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: AnalysisType
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Type of analysis used to obtain the results in this record.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: AnalysisDate
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Date for the record (date on which measurement or test was made. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: Laboratory
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: If a Laboratory performed the analysis, include name and address here.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: ProcedureSummary
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

MineralRecoveryBrine.name: UpdateTimeStamp
MineralRecoveryBrine.description: Date of last time line of data was updated or corrected by the service provider.(Format: 2012-06-22T00:00).

status: Deployed services use version 1.7. Please use this version for future services.  Service and layer name examples with this schema are as follows: service name = SCSeismicHypocenters, layer name = Hypocenter; service name = ARSeismicHypocenters, layer name = Hypocenter
description: This spreadsheet indicates the content requested for features representing Seismic event hypocenter observations. Design is focused on hypocenters portrayed as points with an associated depth. Hypocenter data for geothermal data system is intended as a tool to identify seismically active areas that are often associated with hydrothermal activity, thus the content model does not include detailed information that would be important for seismological analysis; such information should be accessed by including related resource links. As such data should be restricted to records for known or suspected seismic events.
title: Seismic Event Hypocenter
discussion: This template defines the content model for a service that delivers seismic event hypocenter observations. Many of these will be standard map location and IDs, but other information may be delivered. Much of the variation will concern procedures used to recorded events, citations, and possible other collected data that may be useful for geothermal resource research. The seismic event hypocenter template should be used when compiling geo data from maps and field data. The content model presented here is intended to present key information necessary to query a seismic event hypocenter observation service and to evaluate the reported activity and potentially related features (faults).

Hypocenter.name: OBJECTID
Hypocenter.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

Hypocenter.name: HypocenterURI
Hypocenter.description: Unique identifier that specifies the feature represented: e.g. a geologic feature, aquifer or facility structure. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature  to other information related to this feature. For hypocenter observation, data originator should provide hypocenter-specific identifiers; these may have additional prefix strings (e.g. http://resources.usgin.org/uri-gin/…) added to enable dereferencing of http URIs or to ensure global uniqueness.

Hypocenter.name: EventName
Hypocenter.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

Hypocenter.name: EventURI
Hypocenter.description: Unique identifier that specifies the feature represented (seismic event hypocenter). Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature  to other information related to this feature.

Hypocenter.name: Label
Hypocenter.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as feature name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

Hypocenter.name: CatalogSourceCode
Hypocenter.description: See list of codes from http://www.ncedc.org/anss/anss-catalog-source-codes.html on the 'ANSS Source Code Tables' tab.

Hypocenter.name: SeisometerNetwork
Hypocenter.description: Network of individual seismometers used to record and transmit data from tremors.

Hypocenter.name: OriginDateTime
Hypocenter.description: Date for the record (date on which event occurred). Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). Six integers followed by the fraction of a second reported with an appropriate number of significant figures to convey the quality of the origin time. All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

Hypocenter.name: County
Hypocenter.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

Hypocenter.name: State
Hypocenter.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

Hypocenter.name: LatDegree
Hypocenter.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature (use center point for areas); values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

Hypocenter.name: LongDegree
Hypocenter.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature (use center point for areas); values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

Hypocenter.name: SRS
Hypocenter.description: The spatial reference system. It is recommended that an EPSG code be used to identify the SRS used to specify the location.  If an EPSG code is used, identify it as such with the prefix 'EPSG:' For common EPSG codes, see the Data Valid Terms tab. EPSG:4326 is the identifier for WGS84, and should be the text in this field. EPSG stands for European Petroleum Survey Group. EPSSG codes can be dereferenced by putting the code in this URL (replace 4326) http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/4326/.

Hypocenter.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
Hypocenter.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

Hypocenter.name: Depth
Hypocenter.description: Depth of the hypocenter location using an appropriate number of significant digits to convey the quality of the hypocenter. Focal Depth in kilometers below mean sea level.

Hypocenter.name: DepthReferencePoint
Hypocenter.description: Identifier for elevation datum to which other elevations are referred. Default shall be sea level (MSL).

Hypocenter.name: GTEpicenterQuality
Hypocenter.description: GT ("Ground Truth") epicentre quality (km) as claimed by contributor. For example, GT2 means that the submitted epicentre estimate has a 95% chance of lying within 2 km of the true epicentre. See also http://www.isc.ac.uk/gtevents/

Hypocenter.name: GTQualitySupportData
Hypocenter.description:
Availability of information in support of the claimed GT quality, e.g.:
								* RMS of residuals and number of stations used
								* Goodness of fit of synthetics to observed waveforms as a function of depth
								* Quality of depth phases such as pP and sP.

Hypocenter.name: DepthUncertainty
Hypocenter.description: Uncertainty associated with depth measurements/values.

Hypocenter.name: VerticalUnits
Hypocenter.description: Units used to report all elevation and depth information. Default is km for kilometers.

Hypocenter.name: DepthDeterminationMethod
Hypocenter.description: Term that indicates origin of depth determination; one of: fixed, calculated, unknown. This field is used to indicate where a fixed depth is used in hypocenter location calculation. For events distant from any recording station the depth is commonly fixed in the hypocenter location calculation (typically 5 or 10 km). A clear indication where depth was fixed, not calculated, would be useful.

Hypocenter.name: SamplingFeatureType
Hypocenter.description: Feature type is generally a "Hypocenter".

Hypocenter.name: Magnitude
Hypocenter.description: Must be a numeric value.

Hypocenter.name: MagnitudeType
Hypocenter.description: This is a string value, and may be preceded by a min or max indicator. mb, Ms, ML, mbmle, msmle, following ISC database.

Hypocenter.name: StandardMagnitudeError
Hypocenter.description: Standard error associated with the reported magnitude.

Hypocenter.name: EventType
Hypocenter.description: Event classification free text, according to classification scheme used by data provider.

Hypocenter.name: EventTypeTerm
Hypocenter.description: Terms for decomposition of event types using facets of type/subtype, confidence, and intensity.  Encode in type field as {Type [ | Confidence][ | Intensity]}.  Examples  {earthquake | not specified | not specified}, {induced event | suspected},  {earthquake | not specified}.

Hypocenter.name: RelatedFault
Hypocenter.description: Name of fault associated with seismic event, if known. This association does not denote that the earthquake occurred on a particular fault surface. It is meant to provide a means of locating events that may be related to a particular structure. Comment on confidence or basis of relation to a fault in the Notes field.

Hypocenter.name: RelatedFaultURI
Hypocenter.description: Identifier for related fault. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the fault.

Hypocenter.name: Methodology
Hypocenter.description: A brief description of the methodology for hypocenter location, e.g.: Ground survey of known explosion location, with or without information on shot time; InSAR; Local seismographic network data; Analysis of network data that meet criteria of Bondár et al (BSSA, 2004); Special aftershock/main shock studies; Citation of a specific technical report or scientific paper. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

Hypocenter.name: RelatedResource
Hypocenter.description: This may be one to many http links to resources (logs, pictures or other documents if available online. Should be an http:// address (URL)) related to the observation described in each record.

Hypocenter.name: Notes
Hypocenter.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about method, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), etc.

Hypocenter.name: Source
Hypocenter.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining feature; may be author-date type citation, but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe ('|') character.

Hypocenter.name: Shape
Hypocenter.description: Added by GIS for WFS service; this element appears in the xml output, but is generated during service deployment from the latitude and longitude, therefore it doesn't appear in the template.

label: hypocenter

status:
Version 2.0 Schema

Version 2.0.1 has been submitted to NGDS technical team review, the Excel workbook has been adopted for NGDS partner projects and posted on the NGDS web site resources/public documents section. This version is in use in deployed services.  Note that the newest version 2.1 is now available and approved for use.
description: This spreadsheet indicates the content requested for features representing thermal conductivity observations. Design is focused on thermal conductivity measurements/observations portrayed as geospatial points with an associated depth, TC value, headerURI, construction information, and related resources. Thermal Conductivity data for the geothermal data system is intended as a tool to identify areas that may be favorable for geothermal[EP1]  energy production.  Each record should contain measurement values, location, measurement type, and citations for the data.
title: Thermal Conductivity Observation
discussion: This template defines the content model for a service that delivers thermal conductivity observations. Many of these will be standard map location and measurement values, but other information may be delivered. Much of the variation will concern procedures used to record events, citations, and other collected data that may be useful for geothermal resource research. The Thermal Conductivity content model is designed to be used for data compilation [EP2] from published reports, databases, laboratory analysis [EP3] , and field notes. This content model  is intended to present key information necessary to query a thermal conductivity observation service and evaluate the data.

ThermalConductivity.name: OBJECTID
ThermalConductivity.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

ThermalConductivity.name: ObservationURI
ThermalConductivity.description: Unique identifier for this observation. This is the identifier (Uniform Resource Identifier) that will be used to cross-reference data, samples, and other observations to the observation represented by this record. Best practice is to define an http URI that will dereference to a normative description of the observation. USGIN URI's may be redirected to any URL using the http://resources.usgin.org redirector; contact the USGIN development team at AZGS for instructions.

ThermalConductivity.name: ObservationName
ThermalConductivity.description: The human-intelligible name for the observation; may be a concatenation of observation type and feature name.

ThermalConductivity.name: Label
ThermalConductivity.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as observation name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

ThermalConductivity.name: RelatedSampleURI
ThermalConductivity.description: If the thermal conductivity value is based on an average of several samples, multiple observationURIs are listed here, delimited by pipe '|' characters. Recommend use of http URI that will dereference to give representation of sample.

ThermalConductivity.name: OtherID
ThermalConductivity.description: Alternative identifier(s) for observation or site information. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

ThermalConductivity.name: SampleDepth
ThermalConductivity.description: If sample is from the surface enter zero, else put depth of formation sampled.

ThermalConductivity.name: MeasurementUnits
ThermalConductivity.description: Valid choices for depth units = Meters or Feet. If depth is reported as 'surface' or 'missing', select 'meters'.

ThermalConductivity.name: SiteLocationURI
ThermalConductivity.description: Unique identifier that specifies the feature represented: e.g. a geologic feature, aquifer or facility structure. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature.

ThermalConductivity.name: SiteLocationName
ThermalConductivity.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

ThermalConductivity.name: LocalityTerms
ThermalConductivity.description: Additional information or more geographic names associated with sample collection location; if multiple names supplied, delimit with pipe '|' character, e.g. Arizona | La Paz County | Harquahala Mountains | Browns Canyon.

ThermalConductivity.name: County
ThermalConductivity.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

ThermalConductivity.name: State
ThermalConductivity.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

ThermalConductivity.name: LatDegreeWGS84
ThermalConductivity.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature (use center point for areas); values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

ThermalConductivity.name: LongDegreeWGS84
ThermalConductivity.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature (use center point for areas); values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

ThermalConductivity.name: SRS
ThermalConductivity.description: The spatial reference system. It is recommended that an EPSG code be used to identify the SRS used to specify the location.  If an EPSG code is used, identify it as such with the prefix 'EPSG:' For common EPSG codes, see the Data Valid Terms tab. EPSG:4326 is the identifier for WGS84, and should be the text in this field. EPSG stands for European Petroleum Survey Group. EPSSG codes can be dereferenced by putting the code in this URL (replace 4326) http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/4326/.

ThermalConductivity.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
ThermalConductivity.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

ThermalConductivity.name: SampleCollectionDate
ThermalConductivity.description: Date for the record (date on which observation, measurement or test was made or specimen was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

ThermalConductivity.name: SampleMeasurementDate
ThermalConductivity.description: Date for the record (date on which observation, measurement or test was made or specimen was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

ThermalConductivity.name: SampleType
ThermalConductivity.description: Type of material used for sample measurement. Category from simple material classification scheme e.g. rock, sediment, liquid, gas, biological material.

ThermalConductivity.name: SampleShape
ThermalConductivity.description: Shape of sample for measurement: cylinder, square, rectangular, irregular, fine material, coarse material, unknown.

ThermalConductivity.name: SampleDimensionsHeight
ThermalConductivity.description: Description of sample: height of vertical edge. If using a form for cuttings or unconsolidated measurements, put in the values of the form.

ThermalConductivity.name: SampleDimensionsWidth
ThermalConductivity.description: Description of sample: width or radius or horizontal edge. If using a form for cuttings or unconsolidated measurements, put in the values of the form.

ThermalConductivity.name: SampleDimensionsLength
ThermalConductivity.description: Description of sample: length of 2nd horizontal dimension. If using a form for cuttings or unconsolidated measurements, put in the values of the form.

ThermalConductivity.name: SampleDimensionsUnits
ThermalConductivity.description: Units used for height, length and width: centimeters or inches.

ThermalConductivity.name: SampleDensity
ThermalConductivity.description: Density of the rock sample or Bulk Density for Crushed/Cutting samples.

ThermalConductivity.name: UncertaintyDensity
ThermalConductivity.description: Uncertainty of the density of the sample.

ThermalConductivity.name: SampleDensityUnits
ThermalConductivity.description: Units used for density: grams per cubic centimeters (g/cm3) or pound per cubic inch (lb/in3).

ThermalConductivity.name: Laboratory
ThermalConductivity.description: If a Laboratory performed the analysis, include name and address here.

ThermalConductivity.name: MeasurementDevice
ThermalConductivity.description: Type of analysis performed on sample for the measurement: Divided Bar, Portable Divided Bar, Needle Probe, Half-Space Needle Probe, Laser - Infrared, other, unknown.

ThermalConductivity.name: MeasurementProcedure
ThermalConductivity.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check. If following a paper or standard include reference.

ThermalConductivity.name: MeasurementPressure
ThermalConductivity.description: Pressure used on sample during measurement.

ThermalConductivity.name: MeasurementPressureUnits
ThermalConductivity.description: Units for Pressure used on sample during measurement. Valid terms include: Bars or p.s.i. (pounds per square inch).

ThermalConductivity.name: SampleTemperature
ThermalConductivity.description: Temperature, in decimal format, used on sample during measurement. Degrees Celsius is preferred and will be reported for consistency in service implementations.

ThermalConductivity.name: SampleTemperatureUnits
ThermalConductivity.description: Units for Temperature used on sample during measurement. Valid terms include: C (Celsius), F (Fahrenheit), or K (Kelvin).

ThermalConductivity.name: MeasurementDuration
ThermalConductivity.description: Duration of time the sample was under pressure at specified temperature (in minutes).

ThermalConductivity.name: MeasurementDirection
ThermalConductivity.description: If sample is anisotropic then describe direction of sample.

ThermalConductivity.name: MeasurementRun
ThermalConductivity.description: Total number of measurements made on this sample.

ThermalConductivity.name: BulkMixingFormula
ThermalConductivity.description: Method used to calculate Bulk Conductivity if cuttings or unconsolidated material.

ThermalConductivity.name: SaturationFluid
ThermalConductivity.description: Fluid used with rock/sediment material to fill void spaces and saturate (ie: tap water, oil, etc.).

ThermalConductivity.name: SaturatedSampleConductivity
ThermalConductivity.description: Saturated measured conductivity or in situ value.

ThermalConductivity.name: DrySampleConductivity
ThermalConductivity.description: Measured conductivity value of dry rock core or sample.

ThermalConductivity.name: SiteThermalConductivity
ThermalConductivity.description: Determined Thermal Conductivity for sample/formation of rock material.

ThermalConductivity.name: UncertaintyTC
ThermalConductivity.description: Calculated uncertainty of Thermal Conductivity or Bulk Conductivity value.

ThermalConductivity.name: CorrectionTC
ThermalConductivity.description: Correction applied to thermal conductivity for in situ conditions.

ThermalConductivity.name: CorrectionDescription
ThermalConductivity.description: Description of Correction to thermal conductivity.

ThermalConductivity.name: UnitsTC
ThermalConductivity.description: Reporting units for thermal conductivity measurements; SI (Système International) = watts per meter per Kelvin (W m-1 K-1), or other units.

ThermalConductivity.name: SpecificHeat
ThermalConductivity.description: The amount of heat per unit mass required to raise the temperature by one degree Celsius.

ThermalConductivity.name: UncertaintySpecificHeat
ThermalConductivity.description: Report uncertainty if reporting specific heat.

ThermalConductivity.name: SpecificHeatUnits
ThermalConductivity.description: Reporting units for specific heat. Common units are: calorie/gram, joule/gram.

ThermalConductivity.name: ThermalDiffusivity
ThermalConductivity.description: How rapidly a material changes temperature to match the surroundings - equilibrium.

ThermalConductivity.name: UncertaintyThermalDiffusivity
ThermalConductivity.description: Report uncertainty of thermal diffusivity.

ThermalConductivity.name: UnitsThermalDiffusivity
ThermalConductivity.description: Reporting units for Thermal Diffusivity are meters squared per second (m2/s).

ThermalConductivity.name: GeologicFormationName
ThermalConductivity.description: Name of geologic unit that was sampled. Include hierarchy of names if the unit is part of a higher-rank geologic unit, e.g. Group name/Formation name, or Formation/Member, or Group/ Formation. Spell out unit names in full.

ThermalConductivity.name: GeologicFormationURI
ThermalConductivity.description: Unique identifier for the geologic formation of this record.

ThermalConductivity.name: GeologicFormationType
ThermalConductivity.description: Name of sample material type, e.g., granite, sandstone, arkose, schist.

ThermalConductivity.name: DatumElevation
ThermalConductivity.description: The point of reference against which elevation measurements are made. Best practice: use mean sea level (MSL) as datum.

ThermalConductivity.name: Elevation
ThermalConductivity.description: Elevation at ground level for the feature. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL).

ThermalConductivity.name: Permeability
ThermalConductivity.description: The property or capacity of a porous rock, sediment, or soil for transmitting a fluid; it is a measure of the relative ease of fluid flow under unequal pressure.

ThermalConductivity.name: UnitsPermeability
ThermalConductivity.description: Units for the reported permability. The SI unit for permeability is m^2. A practical unit for permeability is the darcy (D), or more commonly the millidarcy (mD) (1 darcy \approx10−12/m^2).

ThermalConductivity.name: Porosity
ThermalConductivity.description: Porosity measures the void or "empty" space in a material; the volume of void over the total volume as a fraction between 0–1. Enter as decimal value.

ThermalConductivity.name: Notes
ThermalConductivity.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about collection method, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

ThermalConductivity.name: MetadataURI
ThermalConductivity.description: URI identifying (and ideally dereferencing to get) a full formal metadata record for the observation report. A time series of observations may all reference the same metadata record that provides contact information and details on procedure, etc.

ThermalConductivity.name: Source
ThermalConductivity.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining feature; may be author-date type citation, but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe '|' character.

ThermalConductivity.name: Shape
ThermalConductivity.description: Added by GIS for WFS service; this element appears in the xml output, but is generated during service deployment from the latitude and longitude, therefore it doesn't appear in the template.

ThermalConductivity.name: OBJECTID
ThermalConductivity.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

ThermalConductivity.name: ObservationURI
ThermalConductivity.description: Unique identifier for this observation. This is the identifier (Uniform Resource Identifier) that will be used to cross-reference data, samples, and other observations to the observation represented by this record. Best practice is to define an http URI that will dereference to a normative description of the observation. USGIN URI's may be redirected to any URL using the http://resources.usgin.org redirector; contact the USGIN development team at AZGS for instructions.

ThermalConductivity.name: ObservationName
ThermalConductivity.description: The human-intelligible name for the observation; may be a concatenation of observation type and feature name.

ThermalConductivity.name: Label
ThermalConductivity.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as observation name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

ThermalConductivity.name: RelatedSampleURI
ThermalConductivity.description: If the thermal conductivity value is based on an average of several samples, multiple observationURIs are listed here, delimited by pipe '|' characters. Recommend use of http URI that will dereference to give representation of sample.

ThermalConductivity.name: OtherID
ThermalConductivity.description: Alternative identifier(s) for observation or site information. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

ThermalConductivity.name: SampleDepth
ThermalConductivity.description: If sample is from the surface enter zero, else put depth of formation sampled.

ThermalConductivity.name: MeasurementUnits
ThermalConductivity.description: Valid choices for depth units = Meters or Feet. If depth is reported as 'surface' or 'missing', select 'meters'.

ThermalConductivity.name: SiteLocationURI
ThermalConductivity.description: Unique identifier that specifies the feature represented: e.g. a geologic feature, aquifer or facility structure. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature.

ThermalConductivity.name: SiteLocationName
ThermalConductivity.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

ThermalConductivity.name: LocalityTerms
ThermalConductivity.description: Additional information or more geographic names associated with sample collection location; if multiple names supplied, delimit with pipe '|' character, e.g. Arizona | La Paz County | Harquahala Mountains | Browns Canyon.

ThermalConductivity.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

ThermalConductivity.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

label: thermalconductivity

status:
Previously deployed services use version 1.6, however version 1.8 has been adopted by the NGDS technical team review. Please use the version 1.8 for all future thermal springs services, which will require differentiating the new version in the name of the service. When deploying with ArcMap products, the newest version does not allow "." in names of web services, so the use of "_" has been implemented as such: WVThermalSprings1_8                   Please use this naming convention for new Thermal Springs services.

SLDs (Styled Layer Descriptors) can be downloaded from the State Geothermal Data Repository.  The legend for the Thermal Springs model is a point-feature color ramp which ranges from green (≤95F) to red (≥ 212F) for each feature.
description: This spreadsheet indicates the content requested for basic data characterizing a hot spring feature for the AASG geothermal data project. Typically, water temperatures are recorded with other information such as water quality or chemical analysis from a particular spring. The temperature and flow rate reported here are meant to be generalized characterization. Other observation services should be used to report time series of temperature or flow measurements.  Chemical analytical data is also reported by a separate observation service. This sheet may be used to compile multiple temperature or flow rate observations for individual springs as well.
title: Thermal/Hot Spring Feature
discussion:
The Thermal Spring URI for a particular spring is the cross-referencing link (foreign key) used to associate the spring record, temperature measurements, chemistry and other information from a particular spring.

Each entry is for one spring.  Multiple observations (such as: temperature observations, chemical analyses) from the same spring would be entered on separate, appropriate spreadsheets/templates.  If these separate observations exist, there should be a link to them entered on the Thermal Spring template, entered under Related Resources.

ThermalSpring.name: OBJECTID
ThermalSpring.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

ThermalSpring.name: ThermalSpringURI
ThermalSpring.description: Unique identifier that specifies the feature represented: e.g. a geologic feature, aquifer or facility structure. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the feature to other information related to this feature.

ThermalSpring.name: SpringName
ThermalSpring.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

ThermalSpring.name: Label
ThermalSpring.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as feature name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

ThermalSpring.name: OtherName
ThermalSpring.description: Other human-intelligible labels for feature such as secondary spring name or common name, other spellings. Indicate the authority from which the OtherName is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

ThermalSpring.name: OtherIdentifier
ThermalSpring.description: Alternative identifier(s) for observation or site information. Indicate the authority from which the OtherID is derived with a short (lower case) prefix delimited by a colon ':' If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'. For example, if a well were known to the Arizona Geological Survey (AZGS) by the id number 1337, the identifier string would be azgs:1337. Any such prefixes used to scope identifiers should be explained in the dataset metadata.

ThermalSpring.name: Description
ThermalSpring.description: Free text field for any additional observations or other information regarding the feature (size, weight, quality, lithology, locality, etc).

ThermalSpring.name: Source
ThermalSpring.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining feature; may be author-date type citation, but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe '|' character.

ThermalSpring.name: SourceURI
ThermalSpring.description: Identifier, DOI or other URI, for the cited source. Ideally an http URI that may be dereferenced to produce a representation of the original source document.

ThermalSpring.name: FeatureType
ThermalSpring.description: Type of spring feature: Hot spring (Spring that issues water with temperature above 50 °C and over 15 °C above mean annual air temperature); Warm spring (Spring that issues water with temperature below 50 °C and 15 C or less above mean annual air temperature); Thermal spring (Spring that issues water with water temperature above body  temperature).

ThermalSpring.name: LandLeaseOwner
ThermalSpring.description: Companies, individuals, or other entities who own the property. Separate multiple with a pipe '|' character.

ThermalSpring.name: OtherLocationName
ThermalSpring.description: Names of geographic features associated with the site that will be useful as search criteria to locate the information for this site. If identifiers from multiple different authorities are available, delimit these identifiers with the pipe character '|'.

ThermalSpring.name: County
ThermalSpring.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

ThermalSpring.name: State
ThermalSpring.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

ThermalSpring.name: PLSS_Meridians
ThermalSpring.description: List north-south baseline and east-west meridian that Townships and Ranges are referenced to.

ThermalSpring.name: Township
ThermalSpring.description: Township in PLSS grid, relative to reported baseline. Formatting and punctuation should be consistent for all locations referenced to the same baseline and meridian. Recommend adding leading '0's so that all number strings are the same length (typically 2 or occasionally 3 digits). Examples 01N, 112S, 001N.

ThermalSpring.name: Range
ThermalSpring.description: Range in PLSS grid, relative to reported meridian. Formatting and punctuation should be consistent for all locations referenced to the same baseline meridian. See instructions on TWP field.

ThermalSpring.name: Section_
ThermalSpring.description: PLSS section number. Must be numeric or null. Some surveys include half sections indicated by a 'nn.5' designation, where n indicates a number.

ThermalSpring.name: SectionPart
ThermalSpring.description: Subdivision of a PLSS section.

ThermalSpring.name: Parcel
ThermalSpring.description: Legal parcel identifier, or block number, or other parcel or location identifier.

ThermalSpring.name: UTM_E
ThermalSpring.description: UTM easting coordinate as decimal number.

ThermalSpring.name: UTM_N
ThermalSpring.description: UTM northing coordinate as decimal number.

ThermalSpring.name: UTMDatumZone
ThermalSpring.description: The datum and UTM zone for the reported coordinates. Datum for most locations should be NAD27 or NAD83.

ThermalSpring.name: LatDegree
ThermalSpring.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature (use center point for areas); values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

ThermalSpring.name: LongDegree
ThermalSpring.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature (use center point for areas); values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

ThermalSpring.name: SRS
ThermalSpring.description: The spatial reference system. It is recommended that an EPSG code be used to identify the SRS used to specify the location.  If an EPSG code is used, identify it as such with the prefix 'EPSG:' For common EPSG codes, see the Data Valid Terms tab. EPSG:4326 is the identifier for WGS84, and should be the text in this field. EPSG stands for European Petroleum Survey Group. EPSSG codes can be dereferenced by putting the code in this URL (replace 4326) http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/4326/.

ThermalSpring.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
ThermalSpring.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

ThermalSpring.name: Temperature
ThermalSpring.description: Temperature, in decimal format. Degrees Celsius is preferred and will be reported for consistency in service implementations.

ThermalSpring.name: TemperatureUnits
ThermalSpring.description: Reporting units are either Celsius (preferred) or Fahrenheit. Use same units throughout this document.

ThermalSpring.name: TempMeasurementProcedure
ThermalSpring.description: Text description of measurement procedure and methods used to calculate corrections.

ThermalSpring.name: TempMeasurementDateTime
ThermalSpring.description: Date for the record (date on which observation, measurement or test was made or specimen was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

ThermalSpring.name: Flow
ThermalSpring.description: Fluid production flow rate, reported in decimal format.

ThermalSpring.name: FlowUnits
ThermalSpring.description: Units for flow rate, either gallons per minute (gpm) or liters per minute (lpm).

ThermalSpring.name: FlowMeasurementProcedure
ThermalSpring.description: Text description of how the measurement was made - instrumentation, logging rate, correction or extrapolation process, how time since circulation was determined, etc. Data provider should indicate QA/QC performed on the data, including individual or institution, time frame and depth of quality check.

ThermalSpring.name: FlowMeasurementDateTime
ThermalSpring.description: Date for the record (date on which observation, measurement or test was made or specimen was collected. Day, month and year must be specified; Excel will display using ISO 8601 date and time (yyyy-mm-ddT:hh:mm) format. If only the year is known, enter month and day as 'Jan. 1', (or '1/1/', or '1-1-', or 'January 1,'). All dates will be converted to yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm.

ThermalSpring.name: MeasurementSource
ThermalSpring.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining this feature or record; may be author-date type citation, well log, report, data files etc., but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe '|' character.

ThermalSpring.name: FlowContinuity
ThermalSpring.description: Continuity of flow terms: Perennial water source (has continuous flow all year long); Intermittent (normally ceases flowing for weeks or months each year); ephermal (flow only for hours or days following rainfall).

ThermalSpring.name: Classification
ThermalSpring.description: "Springs are often classified by the volume of the water they discharge: Magnitude 1 ( > 100 ft³/s); Magnitude 2 (10 to 100 ft³/s); Magnitude 3 (1 to 10 ft³/s); Magnitude 4 (100 US gal/min to 1 ft³/s [448 US gal/min]); Magnitude 5 (10 to 100 gal/minde); Magnitude 6 (1 to 10 gal/min); Magnitude 7 (1 pint to 1 gal/min); Magnitude 8 (Less than 1 pint.min); Magnitude 0 (no flow [sites of past/historic flow]); Magnitude Unknown.

ThermalSpring.name: RelatedWaterChemistry
ThermalSpring.description: None if no chemical data available; a string list of available constituents or analysis types if analyses are available.

ThermalSpring.name: RelatedResources
ThermalSpring.description: Links to additional information. Consists of a collection of {dataType, URL} pairs that would allow automation of access to the related resources.  Delimit multiple values with the pipe character '|' e.g. {wellHeader, http://resources.usgin.org/uri-gin/kgs/well/R13253/} | {photograph, http://geothermaldata.org/resources/photo/145656.tif}.

ThermalSpring.name: Remarks
ThermalSpring.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about collection method, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

ThermalSpring.name: Notes
ThermalSpring.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, details about collection method, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), collection platform or Launch, etc.

ThermalSpring.name: Shape
ThermalSpring.description: Added by GIS for WFS service; this element appears in the xml output, but is generated during service deployment from the latitude and longitude, therefore it doesn't appear in the template.

label: thermalspring

description: This spreadsheet indicates the content requested for features representing active volcanic vent data. This simple content model is intended to identify recently active volcanic vents that may indicate areas of active hydro-thermal systems. Detailed geophysical or geodetic information related to active magma movement and prediction of eruptive activity are out of scope.
title: Volcanic Vents
discussion: This template defines the content model for a service that delivers Volcanic Vent observations. Many of these will be standard map location and IDs, but numerous other measurements may be delivered. Much of the variation will concern procedures used to recorded volcanic data, citations, and possible other collected data that may be useful for geothermal resource research. The Volcanic Vent template should be used when compiling geo data from maps and field data. The content model presented here is intended to present key information necessary to query a volcanic vent observation service and to evaluate the reported activity and potentially related temperature.

VolcanicVent.name: OBJECTID
VolcanicVent.description: Integer record count, added by ArcGIS servers during service deployment; not required but cannot be removed when deploying from ArcGIS feature class. Not user maintained, so this element appears in XML implementation but not in the Content Model Template.

VolcanicVent.name: FeatureURI
VolcanicVent.description: Unique identifier for the volcanic vent described by the elements in this table. Ideally, the identifier is an http URI that will dereference to a known, useful representation of the feature. This identifier will be used to cross reference the sample to other information related to this feature.

VolcanicVent.name: VolcVentName
VolcanicVent.description: Common or human-readable name by which the feature is known. Recommend using only web-safe characters (a-z A-Z 0-9 _-.) in the name. Be consistent in the naming convention used within any given dataset.

VolcanicVent.name: Label
VolcanicVent.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as feature name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

VolcanicVent.name: MapLabel
VolcanicVent.description: Short text string for labeling the feature on maps. Can be the same as feature name. A label may be an OtherLocationName, OtherID or the Name or some combination.

VolcanicVent.name: Description
VolcanicVent.description: Free text field for any additional observations or other information regarding the feature, any special considerations with this instance (size, weight, quality, lithology, locality, etc).

VolcanicVent.name: FeatureType
VolcanicVent.description: Type of Volcanic Vent feature: cone; tuff cone; dome; vent; fissure; shield; remnant stratovolcano; remnant shield volcano; maar; stratovolcano; tuya; monogenetic cone; remnant cone ; remnant dome; resurgent dome.

VolcanicVent.name: VolcanicGroup
VolcanicVent.description: Name of volcanic Group – used if the vent is part of a grouping of volcanoes. E.g. “Wrangells” or “Cook Inlet”.

VolcanicVent.name: UTM_E
VolcanicVent.description: UTM easting coordinate as decimal number.

VolcanicVent.name: UTM_N
VolcanicVent.description: UTM northing coordinate as decimal number.

VolcanicVent.name: UTMDatumZone
VolcanicVent.description: The datum and UTM zone for the reported coordinates. Datum for most locations should be NAD27 or NAD83.

VolcanicVent.name: LatDegree
VolcanicVent.description: Latitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature (use center point for areas); values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

VolcanicVent.name: LongDegree
VolcanicVent.description: Longitude coordinate for the surface location of the feature (use center point for areas); values should be provided with at least 4 significant digits for sufficient precision (7 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p. 6). Use decimal degrees.

VolcanicVent.name: SRS
VolcanicVent.description: The spatial reference system. It is recommended that an EPSG code be used to identify the SRS used to specify the location.  If an EPSG code is used, identify it as such with the prefix 'EPSG:' For common EPSG codes, see the Data Valid Terms tab. EPSG:4326 is the identifier for WGS84, and should be the text in this field. EPSG stands for European Petroleum Survey Group. EPSSG codes can be dereferenced by putting the code in this URL (replace 4326) http://spatialreference.org/ref/epsg/4326/.

VolcanicVent.name: LocationUncertaintyStatement
VolcanicVent.description: Information on how the original location was determined, e.g.: 1:250,000 map, gps unit, Google Earth, PLSS Conversion, Spatial Datum Conversion, e.g., NAD27 to WGS84.

VolcanicVent.name: County
VolcanicVent.description: Required. County name. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. If offshore, specify 'offshore' in this field.

VolcanicVent.name: State
VolcanicVent.description: Required. State name without abbreviations. If unknown or not applicable use 'missing'. For offshore locations, specify the governing or nearest state and list the county as 'offshore'.

VolcanicVent.name: LocationKeyword
VolcanicVent.description: Names of geographic features associated with the site that will be useful as search criteria to locate the information for this site. Separate multiple keywords with the pipe '|' character.

VolcanicVent.name: VentElevation
VolcanicVent.description: Elevation at ground level for the vent. If rim elevation varies, use highest peak. 3 decimal places is recommended by the USGS (OFR 02-463, p.6). Elevations should be reported relative to mean sea level (MSL).

VolcanicVent.name: ElevationUOM
VolcanicVent.description: Units used to report all elevation and depth information.

VolcanicVent.name: RelatedFeature
VolcanicVent.description: Names of geographic features associated with the site that will be useful as search criteria to locate the information for this site. Separate multiple keywords with the pipe '|' character.

VolcanicVent.name: GeologicHistory
VolcanicVent.description: Free text description of age or history of the vent.

VolcanicVent.name: YoungestAge
VolcanicVent.description: Youngest geologic age for material erupted from vent, e.g. Recent, Pleistocene, Miocene.

VolcanicVent.name: OldestAge
VolcanicVent.description: Oldest geologic age for material erupted from vent, e.g. Recent, Pleistocene, Miocene.

VolcanicVent.name: YoungestRadiometricAge_Ma
VolcanicVent.description: Numerical value for the minimum radiometric age for material erupted from the vent expressed in Ma (million years); ex: 4.2.

VolcanicVent.name: OldestRadiometricAge_Ma
VolcanicVent.description: Numerical value for the maximum radiometric age for material erupted from the vent expressed in Ma (million years); ex: 4.2.

VolcanicVent.name: AgeUncertainty_Ma
VolcanicVent.description: Uncertainty of age readings in millions of years.

VolcanicVent.name: AgeSource
VolcanicVent.description: Source of the age dating. Short text explanation of source of information defining feature; may be author-date type citation, but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe '|' character.

VolcanicVent.name: GeologicUnit
VolcanicVent.description: Name of geologic unit that was erupted from the vent. Include hierarchy of names if the unit is part of a higher-rank geologic unit, e.g. groupName/Formation name, or Formation/Member, or Group/Formation/Member/Flow. Spell out unit names in full.

VolcanicVent.name: MaterialComposition
VolcanicVent.description: Volcanic material composition description' e.g. Basalt, Basaltic Andesite, Intermediate, Dacite, Rhyolite, Mixed. If multiple compositions (bimodal, etc) separate, compositions by pipe symbol '|'.

VolcanicVent.name: FlowType
VolcanicVent.description: Term describing eruptive style, e.g. pahoehoe, aa, block-and-ash.

VolcanicVent.name: Notes
VolcanicVent.description: Any additional information to be provided, including description and other data not captured by the template, contact information for related parties (original collector, project PI), etc.

VolcanicVent.name: Source
VolcanicVent.description: Mandatory. Short text explanation of source of information defining feature; may be author-date type citation, but should include some indication of how digital data originated. If unpublished data, provide researcher name, date and research institution for proper citation. Separate multiple citations with pipe '|' character.

VolcanicVent.name: Shape
VolcanicVent.description: Added by GIS for WFS service; this element appears in the xml output, but is generated during service deployment from the latitude and longitude, therefore it doesn't appear in the template.
